**Copenhagen** ^[\[8\]](#cite_note-8)^ ([Danish](/wiki/Danish_language "Danish language"): *København* [\[kʰøpm̩ˈhɑwˀn\]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Danish "Help:IPA/Danish") [](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/e/eb/Da-K%C3%B8benhavn.ogg/Da-K%C3%B8benhavn.ogg.mp3 "Play audio")^[ⓘ](/wiki/File:Da-K%C3%B8benhavn.ogg "File:Da-København.ogg")^) is the capital and most populous city of [Denmark](/wiki/Denmark "Denmark"), with a population of 1.4 million in the [urban area](/wiki/Urban_area_of_Copenhagen "Urban area of Copenhagen").^[\[9\]](#cite_note-Danmarks_Statistik-9)^^[\[10\]](#cite_note-ReferenceA-10)^ The city is situated on the islands of [Zealand](/wiki/Zealand "Zealand") and [Amager](/wiki/Amager "Amager"), separated from [Malmö](/wiki/Malm%C3%B6 "Malmö"), [Sweden](/wiki/Sweden "Sweden"), by the [Øresund](/wiki/%C3%98resund "Øresund") strait. The [Øresund Bridge](/wiki/%C3%98resund_Bridge "Øresund Bridge") connects the two cities by rail and road.{#cite_ref-ReferenceA_10-0}

Originally a [Viking](/wiki/Vikings "Vikings") fishing village established in the 10th century in the vicinity of what is now [Gammel Strand](/wiki/Gammel_Strand "Gammel Strand"), Copenhagen became the capital of Denmark in the early 15th century. During the 16th century, the city served as the *[de facto](/wiki/De_facto "De facto")* capital of the [Kalmar Union](/wiki/Kalmar_Union "Kalmar Union") and the seat of the Union's monarchy, which governed most of the modern-day [Nordic region](/wiki/Nordic_countries "Nordic countries") as part of a Danish [confederation](/wiki/Confederation "Confederation") with [Sweden](/wiki/Sweden "Sweden") and [Norway](/wiki/Norway "Norway"). The city flourished as the cultural and economic centre of [Scandinavia](/wiki/Scandinavia "Scandinavia") during the [Renaissance](/wiki/Renaissance "Renaissance"). By the 17th century, it had become a regional centre of power, serving as the heart of the Danish government and [military](/wiki/Military_history_of_Denmark "Military history of Denmark"). During the 18th century, Copenhagen suffered from a [devastating plague outbreak](/wiki/Great_Northern_War_plague_outbreak "Great Northern War plague outbreak") and urban [conflagrations](/wiki/Conflagration "Conflagration"). Major redevelopment efforts included the construction of the prestigious district of [Frederiksstaden](/wiki/Frederiksstaden "Frederiksstaden") and the establishment of cultural institutions such as the [Royal Theatre](/wiki/Royal_Danish_Theatre "Royal Danish Theatre") and the [Royal Academy of Fine Arts](/wiki/Royal_Danish_Academy_of_Fine_Arts "Royal Danish Academy of Fine Arts"). The city also became the centre of the [Danish slave trade](/wiki/Danish_slave_trade "Danish slave trade") during this period. In 1807, the city was [bombarded by a British fleet](/wiki/Battle_of_Copenhagen_(1807) "Battle of Copenhagen (1807)") during the [Napoleonic Wars](/wiki/Napoleonic_Wars "Napoleonic Wars"), before the [Danish Golden Age](/wiki/Danish_Golden_Age "Danish Golden Age") brought a [Neoclassical look](/wiki/Neoclassical_architecture "Neoclassical architecture") to Copenhagen's architecture. After [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II"), the [Finger Plan](/wiki/Finger_Plan "Finger Plan") fostered the development of housing and businesses along the five urban railway routes emanating from the city centre.

Since the turn of the 21st century, Copenhagen has seen strong urban and cultural development, facilitated by investment in its institutions and infrastructure. The city is the [cultural](/wiki/Culture_of_Denmark "Culture of Denmark"), [economic](/wiki/Economy_of_Denmark "Economy of Denmark") and [governmental](/wiki/Politics_of_Denmark "Politics of Denmark") centre of [Denmark](/wiki/Denmark "Denmark"); it is one of the major financial centres of [Northern Europe](/wiki/Northern_Europe "Northern Europe") with the [Copenhagen Stock Exchange](/wiki/Copenhagen_Stock_Exchange "Copenhagen Stock Exchange"). Copenhagen's economy has developed rapidly in the [service sector](/wiki/Service_sector "Service sector"), especially through initiatives in [information technology](/wiki/Information_technology "Information technology"), [pharmaceuticals](/wiki/Pharmaceuticals "Pharmaceuticals") and [clean technology](/wiki/Clean_technology "Clean technology"). Since the completion of the [Øresund Bridge](/wiki/%C3%98resund_Bridge "Øresund Bridge"), Copenhagen has increasingly integrated with the Swedish province of [Scania](/wiki/Scania "Scania") and its largest city, Malmö, forming the [Øresund Region](/wiki/%C3%98resund_Region "Øresund Region"). With several bridges connecting the various districts, the cityscape is characterised by parks, promenades, and waterfronts. Copenhagen's landmarks such as [Tivoli Gardens](/wiki/Tivoli_Gardens "Tivoli Gardens"), *[The Little Mermaid](/wiki/The_Little_Mermaid_(statue) "The Little Mermaid (statue)")* statue, the [Amalienborg](/wiki/Amalienborg "Amalienborg") and [Christiansborg](/wiki/Christiansborg_Palace "Christiansborg Palace") palaces, [Rosenborg Castle](/wiki/Rosenborg_Castle "Rosenborg Castle"), [Frederik's Church](/wiki/Frederik%27s_Church "Frederik's Church"), [Børsen](/wiki/B%C3%B8rsen "Børsen") and many museums, restaurants and nightclubs are significant tourist attractions.

Copenhagen is home to the [University of Copenhagen](/wiki/University_of_Copenhagen "University of Copenhagen"), the [Technical University of Denmark](/wiki/Technical_University_of_Denmark "Technical University of Denmark"), [Copenhagen Business School](/wiki/Copenhagen_Business_School "Copenhagen Business School"), and the [IT University of Copenhagen](/wiki/IT_University_of_Copenhagen "IT University of Copenhagen"). The University of Copenhagen, founded in 1479, is the oldest university in Denmark. Copenhagen is home to the football clubs [F.C. Copenhagen](/wiki/F.C._Copenhagen "F.C. Copenhagen") and [Brøndby IF](/wiki/Br%C3%B8ndby_IF "Brøndby IF"). The annual [Copenhagen Marathon](/wiki/Copenhagen_Marathon "Copenhagen Marathon") was established in 1980. Copenhagen is one of the most bicycle-friendly cities in the world. [Movia](/wiki/Movia_(transit_agency) "Movia (transit agency)") is the public mass transit company serving all of eastern Denmark, except [Bornholm](/wiki/Bornholm "Bornholm"). The [Copenhagen Metro](/wiki/Copenhagen_Metro "Copenhagen Metro"), launched in 2002, serves central Copenhagen. Additionally, the [Copenhagen S-train](/wiki/S-train_(Copenhagen) "S-train (Copenhagen)"), the [Lokaltog](/wiki/Lokaltog "Lokaltog") ([private railway](https://da.wikipedia.org/wiki/Privatbane "da:Privatbane")), and the [Coast Line](/wiki/Coast_Line_(Denmark) "Coast Line (Denmark)") network serve and connect central Copenhagen to outlying boroughs. Serving roughly 2.5 million passengers a month, [Copenhagen Airport](/wiki/Copenhagen_Airport "Copenhagen Airport"), Kastrup, is the busiest airport in the [Nordic countries](/wiki/Nordic_countries "Nordic countries").  

Etymology {#Etymology}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: Etymology")\]

Copenhagen's name (*København* in Danish), reflects its origin as a harbour and a place of commerce. The original designation in [Old Norse](/wiki/Old_Norse "Old Norse"), from which Danish descends, was ***Kaupmannahǫfn*** [\[ˈkɔupˌmɑnːɑˌhɔvn\]](/wiki/Help:IPA "Help:IPA") (cf. modern [Icelandic](/wiki/Icelandic_language "Icelandic language"): *Kaupmannahöfn* [\[ˈkʰœipˌmanːaˌhœpn̥\]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Icelandic "Help:IPA/Icelandic"), [Faroese](/wiki/Faroese_language "Faroese language"): *Keypmannahavn* [\[ˈtʃʰɛʰpmanːaˌhavn\]](/wiki/Help:IPA "Help:IPA")), meaning 'merchants' harbour'. By the time [Old Danish](/wiki/Old_Danish "Old Danish") was spoken, the capital was called ***Køpmannæhafn*** , with the current name deriving from centuries of subsequent regular [sound change](/wiki/Sound_change "Sound change").

The English [cognates](/wiki/Cognates "Cognates") of the original name would be "[chapman](/wiki/Chapmen "Chapmen")'s [haven](/wiki/Harbor "Harbor")".^[\[11\]](#cite_note-11)^ The English *chapman* , German *Kaufmann*, Dutch *koopman*, Swedish *köpman*, Danish *købmand*, and Icelandic *kaupmaður* share a derivation from Latin *caupo*, meaning 'tradesman'. However, the English term for the city was adapted from its [Low German](/wiki/Low_German "Low German") name, *Kopenhagen*. Copenhagen's [Swedish](/wiki/Swedish_language "Swedish language") name is *Köpenhamn*, a direct translation of the mutually intelligible Danish name.{#cite_ref-11}

The city's Latin name, *Hafnia*, is the namesake of the element [hafnium](/wiki/Hafnium "Hafnium").^[\[12\]](#cite_note-Authier2013-12)^{#cite_ref-Authier2013_12-0}  

History {#History}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section: History")\]  
Main article: [History of Copenhagen](/wiki/History_of_Copenhagen "History of Copenhagen")  
For a chronological guide, see [Timeline of Copenhagen](/wiki/Timeline_of_Copenhagen "Timeline of Copenhagen").
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/K%C3%B8benhavn1500.jpg/220px-K%C3%B8benhavn1500.jpg)](/wiki/File:K%C3%B8benhavn1500.jpg) Reconstruction of Copenhagen  1500  

### Early history {#Early_history}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: Early history")\]

Although the earliest historical records of Copenhagen are from the end of the 12th century, recent [archaeological](/wiki/Archaeological "Archaeological") finds in connection with work on the city's metropolitan rail system revealed the remains of a large merchant's mansion near today's [Kongens Nytorv](/wiki/Kongens_Nytorv "Kongens Nytorv") from  1020. Excavations in [Pilestræde](/wiki/Pilestr%C3%A6de "Pilestræde") have also led to the discovery of a well from the late 12th century. The remains of an ancient church, with graves dating to the 11th century, have been unearthed near where [Strøget](/wiki/Str%C3%B8get "Strøget") meets [Rådhuspladsen](/wiki/R%C3%A5dhuspladsen "Rådhuspladsen").

These finds indicate that Copenhagen's origins as a city go back at least to the 11th century. Substantial discoveries of [flint](/wiki/Flint "Flint") tools in the area provide evidence of human settlements dating to the [Stone Age](/wiki/Stone_Age "Stone Age").^[\[13\]](#cite_note-13)^ Many historians believe the town dates to the late [Viking Age](/wiki/Viking_Age "Viking Age"), and was possibly founded by [Sweyn I Forkbeard](/wiki/Sweyn_Forkbeard "Sweyn Forkbeard").^[\[14\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTECunningham201335-14)^ The natural harbour and good [herring](/wiki/Herring "Herring") stocks seem to have attracted fishermen and merchants to the area on a seasonal basis from the 11th century and more permanently in the 13th century.^[\[15\]](#cite_note-khdsd-15)^ The first habitations were probably centred on [Gammel Strand](/wiki/Gammel_Strand "Gammel Strand") (literally 'old shore') in the 11th century or even earlier.^[\[16\]](#cite_note-16)^{#cite_ref-16}

The earliest written mention of the town was in the 12th century when [Saxo Grammaticus](/wiki/Saxo_Grammaticus "Saxo Grammaticus") in [Gesta Danorum](/wiki/Gesta_Danorum "Gesta Danorum") referred to it as *Portus Mercatorum*, meaning 'Merchants' Harbour' or, in the [Danish](/wiki/Danish_language "Danish language") of the time, *Købmannahavn*.^[\[17\]](#cite_note-metro1415-17)^ Traditionally, Copenhagen's founding has been dated to [Bishop Absalon](/wiki/Absalon "Absalon")'s construction of a modest fortress on the little island of [Slotsholmen](/wiki/Slotsholmen "Slotsholmen") in 1167 where [Christiansborg Palace](/wiki/Christiansborg_Palace "Christiansborg Palace") stands today.^[\[18\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDavies1944365-18)^ The construction of the fortress was in response to attacks by [Wendish](/wiki/Wends "Wends") pirates who plagued the coastline during the 12th century.^[\[19\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarding200938-19)^ Defensive ramparts and moats were completed, and by 1177 St. Clemens Church had been built. Attacks by the Wends continued, and after the original fortress was eventually destroyed by the marauders, islanders replaced it with [Copenhagen Castle](/wiki/Copenhagen_Castle "Copenhagen Castle").^[\[20\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChristopher200678-20)^{#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChristopher200678_20-0}  

### Middle Ages {#Middle_Ages}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: Middle Ages")\]

In 1186, a letter from [Pope Urban III](/wiki/Pope_Urban_III "Pope Urban III") states that the castle of *Hafn* (Copenhagen) and its surrounding lands, including the town of Hafn, were given to [Absalon](/wiki/Absalon "Absalon"), Bishop of Roskilde (1158--1191) and Archbishop of Lund (1177--1201), by King [Valdemar I](/wiki/Valdemar_I_of_Denmark "Valdemar I of Denmark"). Upon Absalon's death, the property was to come into the ownership of the [Bishopric of Roskilde](/wiki/Diocese_of_Roskilde_(Roman-Catholic) "Diocese of Roskilde (Roman-Catholic)").^[\[15\]](#cite_note-khdsd-15)^ Around 1200, the [Church of Our Lady](/wiki/Church_of_Our_Lady_(Copenhagen) "Church of Our Lady (Copenhagen)") was constructed on higher ground to the northeast of the town, which began to develop around it.^[\[15\]](#cite_note-khdsd-15)^{#cite_ref-khdsd_15-2}

As the town became more prominent, it was repeatedly attacked by the [Hanseatic League](/wiki/Hanseatic_League "Hanseatic League"). In 1368, it was successfully invaded during the [Second Danish-Hanseatic War](/wiki/Second_Danish-Hanseatic_War "Second Danish-Hanseatic War"). As the fishing industry thrived in Copenhagen, particularly in the trade of [herring](/wiki/Herring "Herring"), the city began expanding to the north of Slotsholmen.^[\[19\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarding200938-19)^ In 1254, it received a charter as a city under Bishop [Jakob Erlandsen](/wiki/Jakob_Erlandsen "Jakob Erlandsen")^[\[21\]](#cite_note-Copenhagen1898-21)^ who garnered support from the local fishing merchants against the king by granting them special privileges.^[\[22\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBooth20039-22)^ In the mid 1330s, the first land assessment of the city was published.^[\[22\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBooth20039-22)^{#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBooth20039_22-1}

With the establishment of the [Kalmar Union](/wiki/Kalmar_Union "Kalmar Union") (1397--1523) between [Denmark](/wiki/Denmark "Denmark"), [Norway](/wiki/Norway "Norway") and Sweden, by about 1416 Copenhagen had emerged as the capital of Denmark when [Eric of Pomerania](/wiki/Eric_of_Pomerania "Eric of Pomerania") moved his seat to Copenhagen Castle.^[\[23\]](#cite_note-Ingebritsen2006-23)^^[\[20\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChristopher200678-20)^ The [University of Copenhagen](/wiki/University_of_Copenhagen "University of Copenhagen") was inaugurated on 1 June 1479 by King [Christian I](/wiki/Christian_I_of_Denmark "Christian I of Denmark"), following approval from Pope [Sixtus IV](/wiki/Sixtus_IV "Sixtus IV").^[\[24\]](#cite_note-histuni-24)^ This makes it the oldest university in Denmark and [one of the oldest in Europe](/wiki/List_of_medieval_universities "List of medieval universities"). Originally controlled by the [Catholic Church](/wiki/Catholic_Church "Catholic Church"), the university's role in society was forced to change during the [Reformation in Denmark](/wiki/Reformation_in_Denmark%E2%80%93Norway_and_Holstein "Reformation in Denmark–Norway and Holstein") in the late 1530s.^[\[24\]](#cite_note-histuni-24)^{#cite_ref-histuni_24-1}  

### 16th and 17th centuries {#16th_and_17th_centuries}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section: 16th and 17th centuries")\]  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Arsenal_Museum_Copenhagen_backend.jpg/220px-Arsenal_Museum_Copenhagen_backend.jpg)](/wiki/File:Arsenal_Museum_Copenhagen_backend.jpg)  
The [Danish War Museum](/wiki/Danish_War_Museum "Danish War Museum"), the former arsenal  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Old_Stock_Exchange_Copenhagen%2C_pic-001.JPG/220px-Old_Stock_Exchange_Copenhagen%2C_pic-001.JPG)](/wiki/File:Old_Stock_Exchange_Copenhagen,_pic-001.JPG)  
Børsen, the former stock exchange (completed in 1640)

In disputes prior to the Reformation of 1536, the city which had been faithful to [Christian II](/wiki/Christian_II_of_Denmark "Christian II of Denmark"), who was Catholic, was successfully besieged in 1523 by the forces of [Frederik I](/wiki/Frederik_I_of_Denmark "Frederik I of Denmark"), who supported [Lutheranism](/wiki/Lutheranism "Lutheranism"). Copenhagen's defences were reinforced with a series of towers along the city wall. After an extended siege from July 1535 to July 1536, during which the city supported Christian II's alliance with [Malmö](/wiki/Malm%C3%B6 "Malmö") and [Lübeck](/wiki/L%C3%BCbeck "Lübeck"), it was finally forced to capitulate to [Christian III](/wiki/Christian_III_of_Denmark "Christian III of Denmark"). During the second half of the century, the city prospered from increased trade across the [Baltic](/wiki/Baltic_Sea "Baltic Sea") supported by Dutch shipping. [Christoffer Valkendorff](/wiki/Christoffer_Valkendorff "Christoffer Valkendorff"), a high-ranking statesman, defended the city's interests and contributed to its development.^[\[15\]](#cite_note-khdsd-15)^ The Netherlands had also become primarily Protestant, as were northern German states.{#cite_ref-khdsd_15-3}

During the reign of [Christian IV](/wiki/Christian_IV_of_Denmark "Christian IV of Denmark") between 1588 and 1648, Copenhagen had dramatic growth as a city. On his initiative at the beginning of the 17th century, two important buildings were completed on [Slotsholmen](/wiki/Slotsholmen "Slotsholmen"): the [Tøjhus Arsenal](/wiki/T%C3%B8jhus_Museum "Tøjhus Museum") and [Børsen](/wiki/B%C3%B8rsen "Børsen"), the stock exchange. To foster international trade, the [East India Company](/wiki/Danish_East_India_Company "Danish East India Company") was founded in 1616. To the east of the city, inspired by Dutch planning, the king developed the district of [Christianshavn](/wiki/Christianshavn "Christianshavn") with canals and ramparts. It was initially intended to be a fortified trading centre but ultimately became part of Copenhagen.^[\[25\]](#cite_note-kher-25)^ Christian IV also sponsored an array of ambitious building projects including [Rosenborg Slot](/wiki/Rosenborg_Slot "Rosenborg Slot") and the [Rundetårn](/wiki/Rundet%C3%A5rn "Rundetårn").^[\[19\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarding200938-19)^ In 1658--1659, the city withstood a siege by the [Swedes](/wiki/Sweden "Sweden") under [Charles X](/wiki/Charles_X_Gustav_of_Sweden "Charles X Gustav of Sweden") and successfully repelled [a major assault](/wiki/Assault_on_Copenhagen_(1659) "Assault on Copenhagen (1659)").^[\[25\]](#cite_note-kher-25)^{#cite_ref-kher_25-1}

By 1661, Copenhagen had asserted its position as capital of Denmark and Norway. All the major institutions were located there, as was the fleet and most of the army. The defences were further enhanced with the completion of the [Citadel](/wiki/Kastellet,_Copenhagen "Kastellet, Copenhagen") in 1664 and the extension of [Christianshavns Vold](/wiki/Christianshavns_Vold "Christianshavns Vold") with its bastions in 1692, leading to the creation of a new base for the fleet at [Nyholm](/wiki/Holmen,_Copenhagen "Holmen, Copenhagen").^[\[25\]](#cite_note-kher-25)^^[\[26\]](#cite_note-26)^{#cite_ref-26}  

### 18th century {#18th_century}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen&action=edit&section=6 "Edit section: 18th century")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Amalienborg_Palace_%288132069805%29.jpg/220px-Amalienborg_Palace_%288132069805%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Amalienborg_Palace_(8132069805).jpg) Frederik VIII's Palace, also known as Brockdorff Palace in [Frederiksstaden](/wiki/Frederiksstaden "Frederiksstaden"), part of the [Amalienborg Palace](/wiki/Amalienborg_Palace "Amalienborg Palace")

Copenhagen lost around 22,000 of its population of 65,000 to the [plague](/wiki/The_plague_during_the_Great_Northern_War "The plague during the Great Northern War") in 1711.^[\[27\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWoodward199810-27)^ The city was also struck by two major fires that destroyed much of its infrastructure.^[\[20\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChristopher200678-20)^ The [Copenhagen Fire of 1728](/wiki/Copenhagen_Fire_of_1728 "Copenhagen Fire of 1728") was the largest in the history of Copenhagen. It began on the evening of 20 October, and continued to burn until the morning of 23 October, destroying approximately 28% of the city, leaving some 20% of the population homeless. No less than 47% of the medieval section of the city was completely lost. Along with the [1795 fire](/wiki/Copenhagen_fire_of_1795 "Copenhagen fire of 1795"), it is the main reason that few traces of the old town can be found in the modern city.^[\[28\]](#cite_note-28)^^[\[29\]](#cite_note-29)^{#cite_ref-29}

A substantial amount of rebuilding followed. In 1733, work began on the royal residence of [Christiansborg Palace](/wiki/Christiansborg_Palace_(1st) "Christiansborg Palace (1st)"), which was completed in 1745. In 1749, development of the prestigious district of [Frederiksstaden](/wiki/Frederiksstaden "Frederiksstaden") was initiated. Designed by [Nicolai Eigtved](/wiki/Nicolai_Eigtved "Nicolai Eigtved") in the [Rococo](/wiki/Rococo "Rococo") style, its centre contained the mansions which now form [Amalienborg](/wiki/Amalienborg "Amalienborg") Palace.^[\[30\]](#cite_note-30)^ Major extensions to the naval base of [Holmen](/wiki/Holmen_Naval_Base "Holmen Naval Base") were undertaken while the city's cultural importance was enhanced with the [Royal Theatre](/wiki/Royal_Danish_Theatre "Royal Danish Theatre") and the [Royal Academy of Fine Arts](/wiki/Royal_Danish_Academy_of_Fine_Arts "Royal Danish Academy of Fine Arts").^[\[31\]](#cite_note-Københavns_historie_1728-1914-31)^{#cite_ref-Københavns_historie_1728-1914_31-0}

During the 18th century, the [Danish slave trade](/wiki/Danish_slave_trade "Danish slave trade"), which began during the 17th century, underwent a rapid expansion. Between 1660 and 1806, Danish merchants, many of them based out of Copenhagen, transported approximately 120,000 [enslaved Africans](/wiki/Atlantic_slave_trade "Atlantic slave trade") to the [Danish West Indies](/wiki/Danish_West_Indies "Danish West Indies"). These merchants were mostly affiliated with the slave-trading [Danish West India Company](/wiki/Danish_West_India_Company "Danish West India Company") and [Danish Asiatic Company](/wiki/Danish_Asiatic_Company "Danish Asiatic Company"), both of which were headquartered in Copenhagen. Many buildings in Copenhagen, such as the [Moltke Mansion](/wiki/Moltke_Mansion "Moltke Mansion"), [Yellow Palace](/wiki/Yellow_Palace,_Copenhagen "Yellow Palace, Copenhagen") and the [Vestindisk Pakhus](/wiki/Vestindisk_Pakhus "Vestindisk Pakhus") were funded with profits made from the Danish slave trade.^[\[32\]](#cite_note-32)^^[\[33\]](#cite_note-33)^ In the second half of the 18th century, Copenhagen benefited from Denmark's neutrality during the wars between Europe's main powers, allowing it to play an important role in trade between the states around the Baltic Sea. After Christiansborg was destroyed by fire in 1794 and another fire caused serious damage to the city in 1795, work began on the classical Copenhagen landmark of [Højbro Plads](/wiki/H%C3%B8jbro_Plads "Højbro Plads") while [Nytorv](/wiki/Nytorv "Nytorv") and [Gammel Torv](/wiki/Gammel_Torv "Gammel Torv") were converged.^[\[31\]](#cite_note-Københavns_historie_1728-1914-31)^{#cite_ref-Københavns_historie_1728-1914_31-1}  

### 19th century {#19th_century}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: 19th century")\]

As a result of [British](/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Great_Britain_and_Ireland "United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland") fears that Denmark would ally with [France](/wiki/French_First_Republic "French First Republic"), a [Royal Navy](/wiki/Royal_Navy "Royal Navy") fleet under the command of Admiral [Sir Hyde Parker](/wiki/Hyde_Parker_(admiral) "Hyde Parker (admiral)") was dispatched to neutralize the [Royal Dano-Norwegian Navy](/wiki/History_of_the_Danish_navy "History of the Danish navy"). On 2 April 1801, Parker's fleet encountered the Dano-Norwegian navy anchored near Copenhagen. Vice-Admiral [Horatio Nelson](/wiki/Horatio_Nelson,_1st_Viscount_Nelson "Horatio Nelson, 1st Viscount Nelson") led the main attack.^[\[34\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTENelson2005247-34)^ The Dano-Norwegian fleet put up heavy resistance, and the battle is often considered to be Nelson's hardest-fought battle, surpassing even the heavy fighting at [Trafalgar](/wiki/Battle_of_Trafalgar "Battle of Trafalgar").^[\[35\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPocock1994229-35)^ It was during this battle that Lord Nelson was said to have "put the telescope to the blind eye" in order not to see Admiral Parker's signal to [cease fire](/wiki/Ceasefire "Ceasefire"). The British ultimately won the battle, sinking or capturing most of Dano-Norwegian fleet, which led Denmark to agree not to ally with France.^[\[36\]](#cite_note-36)^{#cite_ref-36}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Thoraldsens_Museum.jpg/220px-Thoraldsens_Museum.jpg)](/wiki/File:Thoraldsens_Museum.jpg) Gottlieb Bindesbøll's [Thorvaldsen Museum](/wiki/Thorvaldsen_Museum "Thorvaldsen Museum") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Otto_Bache_-_Soldaternes_hjemkomst_til_K%C3%B8benhavn_i_1849.jpg/220px-Otto_Bache_-_Soldaternes_hjemkomst_til_K%C3%B8benhavn_i_1849.jpg)](/wiki/File:Otto_Bache_-_Soldaternes_hjemkomst_til_K%C3%B8benhavn_i_1849.jpg) Danish soldiers returning to Copenhagen in 1849, after the [First Schleswig War](/wiki/First_Schleswig_War "First Schleswig War") -- painting by [Otto Bache](/wiki/Otto_Bache "Otto Bache") (1894)

In 1807, as a result of continued British fears that Denmark would ally with France, another British fleet led by Admiral [James Gambier](/wiki/James_Gambier,_1st_Baron_Gambier "James Gambier, 1st Baron Gambier") was dispatched to Copenhagen with orders to seize or destroy the Dano-Norwegian navy. The British published a proclamation demanding the surrender of the Dano-Norwegian fleet, and the Danish responded with "what amounted to a declaration of war".^[\[37\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESmith1998204-37)^ Gambier's forces responded by carrying out a naval bombardment of Copenhagen from 2 to 5 September. The bombardment, which saw the deployment of [Congreve rockets](/wiki/Congreve_rocket "Congreve rocket"), killed 195 civilians and wounded 768, along with burning approximately 1,000 structures, including the [Church of Our Lady](/wiki/Church_of_Our_Lady,_Copenhagen "Church of Our Lady, Copenhagen"). Copenhagen's defenders were unable to respond to the bombardment effectively due to relying on an [old defence-line](/wiki/Fortifications_of_Copenhagen "Fortifications of Copenhagen") whose limited range could not reach the British ships and their [longer-range](/wiki/Range_of_a_projectile "Range of a projectile") artillery. A British landing force of 30,000 men entered and occupied Copenhagen; during the battle, the British suffered almost 200 casualties, while the Danish suffered 3,000. Virtually the entire Dano-Norwegian fleet was surrendered to the British, who either burnt them or brought them back to Britain. Denmark declared war on Britain, leading to the outbreak of the [Gunboat War](/wiki/Gunboat_War "Gunboat War"), which lasted until the 1814 [Treaty of Kiel](/wiki/Treaty_of_Kiel "Treaty of Kiel").^[\[38\]](#cite_note-38)^^[\[39\]](#cite_note-39)^^[\[40\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHinde1973168-40)^{#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHinde1973168_40-0}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/KBH_1890-1900.jpg/220px-KBH_1890-1900.jpg)](/wiki/File:KBH_1890-1900.jpg) [Slotsholmen](/wiki/Slotsholmen "Slotsholmen") canal, as seen from the Børsen building ( 1900). In the background from left to right: [Church of the Holy Ghost](/wiki/Church_of_the_Holy_Ghost,_Copenhagen "Church of the Holy Ghost, Copenhagen"), [Trinitatis Complex](/wiki/Trinitatis_Complex "Trinitatis Complex"), [St. Nicholas Church](/wiki/St._Nicholas%27_Church,_Copenhagen "St. Nicholas' Church, Copenhagen"), and [Holmen Church](/wiki/Holmen_Church "Holmen Church").

Despite the turmoil the Napoleonic Wars brought to the city, Copenhagen soon experienced a period of intense cultural creativity known as the [Danish Golden Age](/wiki/Danish_Golden_Age "Danish Golden Age"). Painting prospered under [C.W. Eckersberg](/wiki/C.W._Eckersberg "C.W. Eckersberg") and his students while [C.F. Hansen](/wiki/C.F._Hansen "C.F. Hansen") and [Gottlieb Bindesbøll](/wiki/Gottlieb_Bindesb%C3%B8ll "Gottlieb Bindesbøll") brought a [Neoclassical](/wiki/Neoclassical_architecture "Neoclassical architecture") look to the city's architecture.^[\[41\]](#cite_note-41)^ In the early 1850s, the ramparts of the city were opened to allow new housing to be built around [The Lakes](/wiki/The_Lakes,_Copenhagen "The Lakes, Copenhagen") ([Danish](/wiki/Danish_language "Danish language"): *Søerne* ) that bordered the old defences to the west. By the 1880s, the districts of [Nørrebro](/wiki/N%C3%B8rrebro "Nørrebro") and [Vesterbro](/wiki/Vesterbro,_Copenhagen "Vesterbro, Copenhagen") developed to accommodate those who came from the provinces to participate in the city's industrialization. This dramatic increase of space was long overdue, as not only were the old ramparts out of date as a defence system but bad [sanitation](/wiki/Sanitation "Sanitation") in the old city had to be overcome. From 1886, the west rampart ([Vestvolden](/wiki/Vestvolden "Vestvolden")) was flattened, allowing major extensions to the harbour leading to the establishment of the [Freeport of Copenhagen](/wiki/Freeport_of_Copenhagen "Freeport of Copenhagen") 1892--94.^[\[42\]](#cite_note-42)^ Electricity came in 1892 with electric trams in 1897. The spread of housing to areas outside the old ramparts brought about a huge increase in the population. In 1840, Copenhagen was inhabited by approximately 120,000 people. By 1901, it had some 400,000 inhabitants.^[\[31\]](#cite_note-Københavns_historie_1728-1914-31)^{#cite_ref-Københavns_historie_1728-1914_31-2}  

### 20th century {#20th_century}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: 20th century")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/K%C3%B8benhavn_fra_luften_Dmr_topkbh_k_07121.jpg/220px-K%C3%B8benhavn_fra_luften_Dmr_topkbh_k_07121.jpg)](/wiki/File:K%C3%B8benhavn_fra_luften_Dmr_topkbh_k_07121.jpg) Central Copenhagen in 1939

By the beginning of the 20th century, Copenhagen had become a thriving industrial and administrative city. With its new [city hall](/wiki/Copenhagen_City_Hall "Copenhagen City Hall") and [railway station](/wiki/Copenhagen_Central_Station "Copenhagen Central Station"), its centre was drawn towards the west.^[\[31\]](#cite_note-Københavns_historie_1728-1914-31)^ New housing developments grew up in [Brønshøj](/wiki/Br%C3%B8nsh%C3%B8j "Brønshøj") and [Valby](/wiki/Valby "Valby") while [Frederiksberg](/wiki/Frederiksberg "Frederiksberg") became an enclave within the city of Copenhagen.^[\[43\]](#cite_note-43)^ The northern part of [Amager](/wiki/Amager "Amager") and Valby were also incorporated into the City of Copenhagen in 1901--02.^[\[44\]](#cite_note-44)^{#cite_ref-44}

As a result of Denmark's neutrality in the [First World War](/wiki/First_World_War "First World War"), Copenhagen prospered from trade with both Britain and Germany while the city's defences were kept fully manned by some 40,000 soldiers for the duration of the war.^[\[45\]](#cite_note-45)^{#cite_ref-45}

In the 1920s there were serious shortages of goods and housing. Plans were drawn up to demolish the old part of Christianshavn and to get rid of the worst of the city's slum areas.^[\[46\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchaldemose2005161-46)^ However, it was not until the 1930s that substantial housing developments ensued,^[\[47\]](#cite_note-Københavns_historie_siden_1914-47)^ with the demolition of one side of Christianhavn's [Torvegade](/wiki/Torvegade "Torvegade") to build five large blocks of flats.^[\[46\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchaldemose2005161-46)^{#cite_ref-FOOTNOTESchaldemose2005161_46-1}  

#### World War II {#World_War_II}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section: World War II")\]  
See also: [Denmark in World War II](/wiki/Denmark_in_World_War_II "Denmark in World War II") and [Danish resistance movement](/wiki/Danish_resistance_movement "Danish resistance movement")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Shellhuset_210345.jpg/220px-Shellhuset_210345.jpg)](/wiki/File:Shellhuset_210345.jpg) The RAF's bombing of the [Gestapo](/wiki/Gestapo "Gestapo") headquarters in March 1945 was coordinated with the Danish resistance movement. [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/People_celebrating_the_liberation_of_Denmark._5th_May_1945._At_Str%C3%B8get_in_Copenhagen..jpg/220px-People_celebrating_the_liberation_of_Denmark._5th_May_1945._At_Str%C3%B8get_in_Copenhagen..jpg)](/wiki/File:People_celebrating_the_liberation_of_Denmark._5th_May_1945._At_Str%C3%B8get_in_Copenhagen..jpg) People celebrating the [liberation of Denmark](/wiki/Liberation_of_Denmark "Liberation of Denmark") at Strøget in Copenhagen, 5 May 1945. Germany surrendered three days later.

[In Denmark during World War II](/wiki/Denmark_in_World_War_II "Denmark in World War II"), Copenhagen was [occupied by German troops](/wiki/Occupation_of_Denmark "Occupation of Denmark") along with the rest of the country from 9 April 1940 until 4 May 1945. German leader [Adolf Hitler](/wiki/Adolf_Hitler "Adolf Hitler") hoped that Denmark would be "a model [protectorate](/wiki/Protectorate "Protectorate")"^[\[48\]](#cite_note-48)^ and initially the [Nazi](/wiki/Nazism "Nazism") authorities sought to arrive at an understanding with the Danish government. The [1943 Danish parliamentary election](/wiki/1943_Danish_Folketing_election "1943 Danish Folketing election") was also allowed to take place, with only the [Communist Party](/wiki/Communist_Party_of_Denmark "Communist Party of Denmark") excluded. But in August 1943, after the government's collaboration with the occupation forces collapsed, several ships were sunk in Copenhagen Harbor by the [Royal Danish Navy](/wiki/Royal_Danish_Navy "Royal Danish Navy") to prevent their use by the Germans. Around that time the Nazis [started to arrest Jews](/wiki/Racial_policy_of_Nazi_Germany "Racial policy of Nazi Germany"), although [most managed to escape to Sweden](/wiki/Rescue_of_the_Danish_Jews "Rescue of the Danish Jews").^[\[49\]](#cite_note-occupation-49)^{#cite_ref-occupation_49-0}

In 1945 [Ole Lippman](/wiki/Ole_Lippman "Ole Lippman"), leader of the Danish section of the [Special Operations Executive](/wiki/Special_Operations_Executive "Special Operations Executive"), invited the British [Royal Air Force](/wiki/Royal_Air_Force "Royal Air Force") to assist their operations by attacking Nazi headquarters in Copenhagen. Accordingly, air vice-marshal [Sir Basil Embry](/wiki/Basil_Embry "Basil Embry") drew up plans for a spectacular precision attack on the [Sicherheitsdienst](/wiki/Sicherheitsdienst "Sicherheitsdienst") and [Gestapo](/wiki/Gestapo "Gestapo") building, the former offices of the [Shell Oil Company](/wiki/Shell_Oil_Company "Shell Oil Company"). Political prisoners were kept in the attic to prevent an air raid, so the RAF had to bomb the lower levels of the building.^[\[50\]](#cite_note-milhist.dk-50)^{#cite_ref-milhist.dk_50-0}

The attack, known as "[Operation Carthage](/wiki/Operation_Carthage "Operation Carthage")", came on 22 March 1945, in three small waves. In the first wave, all six planes (carrying one bomb each) hit their target, but one of the aircraft crashed near Frederiksberg Girls School. Because of this crash, four of the planes in the two following waves assumed the school was the military target and aimed their bombs at the school, leading to the death of 123 civilians (of which 87 were schoolchildren).^[\[50\]](#cite_note-milhist.dk-50)^ However, 18 of the 26 political prisoners in the Shell Building managed to escape while the Gestapo archives were completely destroyed.^[\[50\]](#cite_note-milhist.dk-50)^{#cite_ref-milhist.dk_50-2}

On 8 May 1945 Copenhagen was officially liberated by British troops commanded by [Field Marshal](/wiki/Field_Marshal "Field Marshal") [Bernard Montgomery](/wiki/Bernard_Montgomery "Bernard Montgomery") who supervised the surrender of 30,000 Germans situated around the capital.^[\[51\]](#cite_note-51)^{#cite_ref-51}  

#### Post-war decades {#Post-war_decades}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section: Post-war decades")\]

Shortly after the end of the war, an innovative urban development project known as the [Finger Plan](/wiki/Finger_Plan "Finger Plan") was introduced in 1947, encouraging the creation of new housing and businesses interspersed with large green areas along five "fingers" stretching out from the city centre along the [S-train](/wiki/S-train "S-train") routes.^[\[52\]](#cite_note-OECD2010-52)^^[\[53\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTECervero1998132-53)^ With the expansion of the welfare state and women entering the work force, schools, nurseries, sports facilities and hospitals were established across the city. As a result of student unrest in the late 1960s, the former Bådsmandsstræde Barracks in [Christianshavn](/wiki/Christianshavn "Christianshavn") was occupied, leading to the establishment of [Freetown Christiania](/wiki/Freetown_Christiania "Freetown Christiania") in September 1971.^[\[54\]](#cite_note-kkkh-54)^{#cite_ref-kkkh_54-0}

Motor traffic in the city grew significantly and in 1972 the trams were replaced by buses. From the 1960s, on the initiative of the young architect [Jan Gehl](/wiki/Jan_Gehl "Jan Gehl"), pedestrian streets and cycle tracks were created in the city centre.^[\[55\]](#cite_note-55)^ Activity in the port of Copenhagen declined with the closure of the Holmen Naval Base. [Copenhagen Airport](/wiki/Copenhagen_Airport "Copenhagen Airport") underwent considerable expansion, becoming a hub for the [Nordic countries](/wiki/Nordic_countries "Nordic countries"). In the 1990s, large-scale housing developments were realised in the harbour area and in the west of [Amager](/wiki/Amager "Amager").^[\[47\]](#cite_note-Københavns_historie_siden_1914-47)^ The national library's [Black Diamond](/wiki/Black_Diamond_(library) "Black Diamond (library)") building on the waterfront was completed in 1999.^[\[56\]](#cite_note-56)^{#cite_ref-56}

### 21st century {#21st_century}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen&action=edit&section=12 "Edit section: 21st century")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Copenhagen_Opera_House_2014_04.jpg/220px-Copenhagen_Opera_House_2014_04.jpg)](/wiki/File:Copenhagen_Opera_House_2014_04.jpg) Copenhagen Opera House

Since the summer of 2000, Copenhagen and the Swedish city of [Malmö](/wiki/Malm%C3%B6 "Malmö") have been connected by the [Øresund Bridge](/wiki/%C3%98resund_Bridge "Øresund Bridge"), which carries rail and road traffic. As a result, Copenhagen has become the centre of a larger metropolitan area spanning both nations. The bridge has brought about considerable changes in the public [transport system](/wiki/Transport_network "Transport network") and has led to the extensive redevelopment of [Amager](/wiki/Amager "Amager").^[\[54\]](#cite_note-kkkh-54)^ The city's service and trade sectors have developed while a number of banking and financial institutions have been established. Educational institutions have also gained importance, especially the [University of Copenhagen](/wiki/University_of_Copenhagen "University of Copenhagen") with its 35,000 students.^[\[57\]](#cite_note-57)^ Another important development for the city has been the [Copenhagen Metro](/wiki/Copenhagen_Metro "Copenhagen Metro"), the railway system which opened in 2002 with additions until 2007, transporting some 54 million passengers by 2011.^[\[58\]](#cite_note-58)^{#cite_ref-58}

On the cultural front, the [Copenhagen Opera House](/wiki/Copenhagen_Opera_House "Copenhagen Opera House"), a gift to the city from the shipping magnate [Mærsk Mc-Kinney Møller](/wiki/M%C3%A6rsk_Mc-Kinney_M%C3%B8ller "Mærsk Mc-Kinney Møller") on behalf of the A.P. Møller foundation, was completed in 2004.^[\[59\]](#cite_note-59)^ In December 2009 Copenhagen gained international prominence when it hosted the worldwide climate meeting [COP15](/wiki/COP15 "COP15").^[\[60\]](#cite_note-60)^{#cite_ref-60}

On 3 July 2022, three people were killed in [a shooting](/wiki/2022_Copenhagen_mall_shooting "2022 Copenhagen mall shooting") at [Field's](/wiki/Field%27s "Field's") mall in Copenhagen. Police chief inspector Søren Thomassen announced the arrest of a 22-year-old man and said that the police cannot rule out an act of terrorism.^[\[61\]](#cite_note-61)^^[\[62\]](#cite_note-62)^{#cite_ref-62}  

Geography {#Geography}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen&action=edit&section=13 "Edit section: Geography")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/Copenhagen_by_Sentinel-2%2C_2020-06-15.jpg/220px-Copenhagen_by_Sentinel-2%2C_2020-06-15.jpg)](/wiki/File:Copenhagen_by_Sentinel-2,_2020-06-15.jpg) Satellite image of Copenhagen [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/CphUrbanAreaOnPoliticalMap2.png/220px-CphUrbanAreaOnPoliticalMap2.png)](/wiki/File:CphUrbanAreaOnPoliticalMap2.png) The red line shows the approximate extent of the urban area of Copenhagen. [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Copenhagen_Metropolitan_Area.JPG/220px-Copenhagen_Metropolitan_Area.JPG)](/wiki/File:Copenhagen_Metropolitan_Area.JPG) Copenhagen metropolitan area

Copenhagen is part of the [Øresund Region](/wiki/%C3%98resund_Region "Øresund Region"), which consists of [Zealand](/wiki/Zealand "Zealand"), [Lolland-Falster](/wiki/Lolland-Falster "Lolland-Falster") and [Bornholm](/wiki/Bornholm "Bornholm") in Denmark and [Scania](/wiki/Scania "Scania") in Sweden.^[\[63\]](#cite_note-63)^ It is located on the eastern shore of the island of Zealand, partly on the island of [Amager](/wiki/Amager "Amager") and on a number of natural and artificial islets between the two. Copenhagen faces the [Øresund](/wiki/%C3%98resund "Øresund") to the east, the strait of water that separates Denmark from Sweden, and which connects the [North Sea](/wiki/North_Sea "North Sea") with the [Baltic Sea](/wiki/Baltic_Sea "Baltic Sea"). The [Swedish](/wiki/Sweden "Sweden") city of [Malmö](/wiki/Malm%C3%B6 "Malmö") and the town of [Landskrona](/wiki/Landskrona "Landskrona") lie on the Swedish side of the sound directly across from Copenhagen.^[\[64\]](#cite_note-64)^ By road, Copenhagen is 42 kilometres (26 mi) northwest of [Malmö](/wiki/Malm%C3%B6 "Malmö"), Sweden, 85 kilometres (53 mi) northeast of [Næstved](/wiki/N%C3%A6stved "Næstved"), 164 kilometres (102 mi) northeast of [Odense](/wiki/Odense "Odense"), 295 kilometres (183 mi) east of [Esbjerg](/wiki/Esbjerg "Esbjerg") and 188 kilometres (117 mi) southeast of [Aarhus](/wiki/Aarhus "Aarhus") by sea and road via [Sjællands Odde](/wiki/Sj%C3%A6llands_Odde "Sjællands Odde").^[\[65\]](#cite_note-65)^{#cite_ref-65}

The city centre lies in the area originally defined by the old [ramparts](/wiki/Rampart_(fortification) "Rampart (fortification)"), which are still referred to as the [Fortification Ring](/wiki/Fortification_Ring,_Copenhagen "Fortification Ring, Copenhagen") (*Fæstningsringen* ) and kept as a partial green band around it.^[\[66\]](#cite_note-66)^ Then come the late-19th- and early-20th-century residential neighbourhoods of [Østerbro](/wiki/%C3%98sterbro "Østerbro"), [Nørrebro](/wiki/N%C3%B8rrebro "Nørrebro"), [Vesterbro](/wiki/Vesterbro,_Copenhagen "Vesterbro, Copenhagen") and [Amagerbro](/wiki/Amagerbro "Amagerbro"). The outlying areas of [Kongens Enghave](/wiki/Kongens_Enghave "Kongens Enghave"), [Valby](/wiki/Valby "Valby"), [Vigerslev](/wiki/Vigerslev "Vigerslev"), [Vanløse](/wiki/Vanl%C3%B8se "Vanløse"), [Brønshøj](/wiki/Br%C3%B8nsh%C3%B8j "Brønshøj"), [Utterslev](/wiki/Utterslev "Utterslev") and [Sundby](/wiki/Sundby,_Copenhagen "Sundby, Copenhagen") followed from 1920 to 1960. They consist mainly of residential housing and apartments often enhanced with parks and greenery.^[\[67\]](#cite_note-kgdsd-67)^{#cite_ref-kgdsd_67-0}  

### Topography {#Topography}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen&action=edit&section=14 "Edit section: Topography")\]

The central area of the city consists of relatively low-lying flat ground formed by [moraines](/wiki/Moraine "Moraine") from the last ice age while the hilly areas to the north and west frequently rise to 50 m (160 ft) above sea level. The slopes of [Valby](/wiki/Valby "Valby") and [Brønshøj](/wiki/Br%C3%B8nsh%C3%B8j "Brønshøj") reach heights of over 30 m (98 ft), divided by valleys running from the northeast to the southwest. Close to the centre are the [Copenhagen lakes](/wiki/The_Lakes,_Copenhagen "The Lakes, Copenhagen") of Sortedams Sø, Peblinge Sø and Sankt Jørgens Sø.^[\[67\]](#cite_note-kgdsd-67)^{#cite_ref-kgdsd_67-1}

Copenhagen rests on a [subsoil](/wiki/Subsoil "Subsoil") of flint-layered limestone deposited in the [Danian](/wiki/Danian "Danian") period some 60 to 66 million years ago. Some [greensand](/wiki/Greensand_(geology) "Greensand (geology)") from the [Selandian](/wiki/Selandian "Selandian") is also present. There are a few faults in the area, the most important of which is the Carlsberg fault which runs northwest to southeast through the centre of the city.^[\[68\]](#cite_note-68)^ During the last ice age, glaciers eroded the surface leaving a layer of moraines up to 15 m (49 ft) thick.^[\[69\]](#cite_note-69)^{#cite_ref-69}

[Geologically](/wiki/Geology "Geology"), Copenhagen lies in the northern part of Denmark where the land is rising because of [post-glacial rebound](/wiki/Post-glacial_rebound "Post-glacial rebound").  

### Beaches {#Beaches}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen&action=edit&section=15 "Edit section: Beaches")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Amager_Strandpark_-_kite_surfers.jpg/220px-Amager_Strandpark_-_kite_surfers.jpg)](/wiki/File:Amager_Strandpark_-_kite_surfers.jpg) Amager Strandpark [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Kopenhagen%2C_Kalvebod_B%C3%B8lge.jpg/220px-Kopenhagen%2C_Kalvebod_B%C3%B8lge.jpg)](/wiki/File:Kopenhagen,_Kalvebod_B%C3%B8lge.jpg) Kalvebod Bølge -- public beach within the city

[Amager Strandpark](/wiki/Amager_Strandpark "Amager Strandpark"), which opened in 2005, is a 2 km (1 mi) long [artificial island](/wiki/Artificial_island "Artificial island"), with a total of 4.6 km (2.9 mi) of beaches. It is located just 15 minutes by bicycle or a few minutes by metro from the city centre.^[\[70\]](#cite_note-70)^ In [Klampenborg](/wiki/Klampenborg "Klampenborg"), about 10 kilometres (6.2 mi) from downtown Copenhagen, is [Bellevue Beach](/wiki/Bellevue_Beach "Bellevue Beach"). It is 700 metres (2,300 ft) long and has both lifeguards and freshwater showers on the beach.^[\[71\]](#cite_note-71)^{#cite_ref-71}

The beaches are supplemented by a system of [Harbour Baths](/wiki/Copenhagen_Harbour_Baths "Copenhagen Harbour Baths") along the Copenhagen waterfront. The first and most popular of these is located at [Islands Brygge](/wiki/Islands_Brygge "Islands Brygge"), literally meaning Iceland's Quay, and has won international acclaim for its design.^[\[72\]](#cite_note-72)^{#cite_ref-72}  

Climate {#Climate}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen&action=edit&section=16 "Edit section: Climate")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Frederiksberg_Palace_from_above_%28winter%29.JPG/220px-Frederiksberg_Palace_from_above_%28winter%29.JPG)](/wiki/File:Frederiksberg_Palace_from_above_(winter).JPG) [Frederiksberg Palace](/wiki/Frederiksberg_Palace "Frederiksberg Palace") in winter

Copenhagen is in the [oceanic climate](/wiki/Oceanic_climate "Oceanic climate") zone ([Köppen](/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification "Köppen climate classification"): *Cfb* ).^[\[73\]](#cite_note-73)^ Its weather is subject to [low-pressure systems](/wiki/Low_pressure_area "Low pressure area") from the [Atlantic](/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean "Atlantic Ocean") which result in unstable conditions throughout the year. Apart from slightly higher rainfall from July to September, precipitation is moderate. While snowfall occurs mainly from late December to early March, there can also be rain, with average temperatures around the freezing point.^[\[74\]](#cite_note-74)^{#cite_ref-74}

June is the sunniest month of the year with an average of about eight hours of sunshine a day. July is the warmest month with an average daytime high of 21 °C. By contrast, the average hours of sunshine are less than two per day in November and only one and a half per day from December to February. In the spring, it gets warmer again with four to six hours of sunshine per day from March to May. February is the driest month of the year.^[\[75\]](#cite_note-75)^ Exceptional weather conditions can bring as much as 50 cm of snow to Copenhagen in a 24-hour period during the winter months^[\[76\]](#cite_note-76)^ while summer temperatures have been known to rise to heights of 33 °C (91 °F).^[\[77\]](#cite_note-77)^{#cite_ref-77}

Because of Copenhagen's northern latitude, the number of daylight hours varies considerably between summer and winter. On the summer solstice, the sun rises at 04:26 and sets at 21:58, providing 17 hours 32 minutes of daylight. On the winter solstice, it rises at 08:37 and sets at 15:39 with 7 hours and 1 minute of daylight. There is therefore a difference of 10 hours and 31 minutes in the length of days and nights between the summer and winter solstices.^[\[78\]](#cite_note-78)^{#cite_ref-78}

Administration {#Administration}
--------------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen&action=edit&section=17 "Edit section: Administration")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/Copenhagen_City_Hall_on_R%C3%A5dhuspladsen_%28City_Hall_Square%29.jpg/260px-Copenhagen_City_Hall_on_R%C3%A5dhuspladsen_%28City_Hall_Square%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Copenhagen_City_Hall_on_R%C3%A5dhuspladsen_(City_Hall_Square).jpg) Copenhagen City Hall (right) on City Hall Square in the city centre

According to [Statistics Denmark](/wiki/Statistics_Denmark "Statistics Denmark"), the [urban area of Copenhagen](/wiki/Urban_area_of_Copenhagen "Urban area of Copenhagen") (*Hovedstadsområdet*) consists of the [municipalities](/wiki/Municipalities_of_Denmark "Municipalities of Denmark") of [Copenhagen](/wiki/Copenhagen_Municipality "Copenhagen Municipality"), [Frederiksberg](/wiki/Frederiksberg_Municipality "Frederiksberg Municipality"), [Albertslund](/wiki/Albertslund_Municipality "Albertslund Municipality"), [Brøndby](/wiki/Br%C3%B8ndby_Municipality "Brøndby Municipality"), [Gentofte](/wiki/Gentofte_Municipality "Gentofte Municipality"), [Gladsaxe](/wiki/Gladsaxe_Municipality "Gladsaxe Municipality"), [Glostrup](/wiki/Glostrup_Municipality "Glostrup Municipality"), [Herlev](/wiki/Herlev_Municipality "Herlev Municipality"), [Hvidovre](/wiki/Hvidovre_Municipality "Hvidovre Municipality"), [Lyngby-Taarbæk](/wiki/Lyngby-Taarb%C3%A6k_Municipality "Lyngby-Taarbæk Municipality"), [Rødovre](/wiki/R%C3%B8dovre_Municipality "Rødovre Municipality"), [Tårnby](/wiki/T%C3%A5rnby_Municipality "Tårnby Municipality") and [Vallensbæk](/wiki/Vallensb%C3%A6k_Municipality "Vallensbæk Municipality") as well as parts of [Ballerup](/wiki/Ballerup_Municipality "Ballerup Municipality"), [Rudersdal](/wiki/Rudersdal_Municipality "Rudersdal Municipality") and [Furesø](/wiki/Fures%C3%B8_Municipality "Furesø Municipality") municipalities, along with the cities of [Ishøj](/wiki/Ish%C3%B8j "Ishøj") and [Greve Strand](/wiki/Greve_Strand "Greve Strand").^[\[6\]](#cite_note-pop1-6)^^[\[84\]](#cite_note-urban-84)^ They are located in the [Capital Region](/wiki/Capital_Region_of_Denmark "Capital Region of Denmark") (*Region Hovedstaden*). Municipalities are responsible for a wide variety of [public services](/wiki/Public_service "Public service"), which include land-use planning, environmental planning, public housing, management and maintenance of local roads, and social security. Municipal administration is also conducted by a [mayor](/wiki/List_of_lord_mayors_of_Copenhagen "List of lord mayors of Copenhagen"), a [council](/wiki/Copenhagen_City_Council "Copenhagen City Council"), and an executive.^[\[85\]](#cite_note-85)^{#cite_ref-85}

Copenhagen Municipality is by far the largest municipality, with the historic city at its core. The seat of Copenhagen's municipal council is the [Copenhagen City Hall](/wiki/Copenhagen_City_Hall "Copenhagen City Hall") (**Rådhus** ), which is situated on [City Hall Square](/wiki/City_Hall_Square,_Copenhagen "City Hall Square, Copenhagen"). The second largest municipality is Frederiksberg, an enclave within Copenhagen Municipality.

Copenhagen Municipality is divided into [ten districts](/wiki/Districts_of_Copenhagen "Districts of Copenhagen") (*bydele* ):^[\[86\]](#cite_note-Københavns_bydele-86)^ [Indre By](/wiki/Indre_By "Indre By"), [Østerbro](/wiki/%C3%98sterbro "Østerbro"), [Nørrebro](/wiki/N%C3%B8rrebro "Nørrebro"), [Vesterbro/Kongens Enghave](/wiki/Vesterbro/Kongens_Enghave "Vesterbro/Kongens Enghave"), [Valby](/wiki/Valby "Valby"), [Vanløse](/wiki/Vanl%C3%B8se "Vanløse"), [Brønshøj-Husum](/wiki/Br%C3%B8nsh%C3%B8j-Husum "Brønshøj-Husum"), [Bispebjerg](/wiki/Bispebjerg "Bispebjerg"), [Amager Øst](/wiki/Amager_%C3%98st "Amager Øst"), and [Amager Vest](/wiki/Amager_Vest "Amager Vest"). Neighbourhoods of Copenhagen include [Slotsholmen](/wiki/Slotsholmen "Slotsholmen"), [Frederiksstaden](/wiki/Frederiksstaden "Frederiksstaden"), [Islands Brygge](/wiki/Islands_Brygge "Islands Brygge"), [Holmen](/wiki/Holmen,_Copenhagen "Holmen, Copenhagen"), [Christiania](/wiki/Freetown_Christiania "Freetown Christiania"), [Carlsberg](/wiki/Carlsberg_(district) "Carlsberg (district)"), [Sluseholmen](/wiki/Sluseholmen "Sluseholmen"), [Sydhavn](/wiki/Kongens_Enghave "Kongens Enghave"), [Amagerbro](/wiki/Amagerbro "Amagerbro"), [Ørestad](/wiki/%C3%98restad "Ørestad"), [Nordhavnen](/wiki/Nordhavnen "Nordhavnen"), [Bellahøj](/wiki/Bellah%C3%B8j "Bellahøj"), [Brønshøj](/wiki/Br%C3%B8nsh%C3%B8j "Brønshøj"), [Ryparken](/wiki/Ryparken "Ryparken"), and [Vigerslev](/wiki/Vigerslev "Vigerslev").{#cite_ref-Københavns_bydele_86-0}  

### Law and order {#Law_and_order}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen&action=edit&section=18 "Edit section: Law and order")\]

Most of Denmark's top legal courts and institutions are based in Copenhagen. A modern-style court of justice, *[Hof- og Stadsretten](/wiki/Hof-_og_Stadsretten "Hof- og Stadsretten")* , was introduced in Denmark, specifically for Copenhagen, by [Johann Friedrich Struensee](/wiki/Johann_Friedrich_Struensee "Johann Friedrich Struensee") in 1771.^[\[87\]](#cite_note-87)^ Now known as the [City Court of Copenhagen](/wiki/Copenhagen_Court_House "Copenhagen Court House") (*Københavns Byret*), it is the largest of the 24 city courts in Denmark with jurisdiction over the municipalities of Copenhagen, [Dragør](/wiki/Drag%C3%B8r "Dragør") and [Tårnby](/wiki/T%C3%A5rnby "Tårnby"). With its 42 judges, it has a Probate Division, an Enforcement Division and a Registration and Notorial Acts Division while bankruptcy is handled by the [Maritime and Commercial Court of Copenhagen](/wiki/Maritime_and_Commercial_Court_(Denmark) "Maritime and Commercial Court (Denmark)").^[\[88\]](#cite_note-88)^ Established in 1862, the Maritime and Commercial Court (*Sø- og Handelsretten*) also hears commercial cases including those relating to trade marks, marketing practices and competition for the whole of Denmark.^[\[89\]](#cite_note-89)^ Denmark's [Supreme Court](/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Denmark "Supreme Court of Denmark") (*Højesteret*), located in [Christiansborg Palace](/wiki/Christiansborg_Palace "Christiansborg Palace") on Prins Jørgens Gård in the centre of Copenhagen, is the country's final court of appeal. Handling civil and criminal cases from the subordinate courts, it has two chambers which each hear all types of cases.^[\[90\]](#cite_note-90)^{#cite_ref-90}

The [Danish National Police](/wiki/Danish_National_Police "Danish National Police") and Copenhagen Police headquarters is situated in the Neoclassical-inspired [Politigården](/wiki/Copenhagen_Police_Headquarters "Copenhagen Police Headquarters") building built in 1918--1924 under architects [Hack Kampmann](/wiki/Hack_Kampmann "Hack Kampmann") and [Holger Alfred Jacobsen](/wiki/Holger_Jacobsen "Holger Jacobsen"). The building also contains administration, management, emergency department and radio service offices.^[\[91\]](#cite_note-91)^{#cite_ref-91}

The [Copenhagen Fire Department](/wiki/Copenhagen_Fire_Department "Copenhagen Fire Department") forms the largest municipal fire brigade in Denmark with some 500 fire and ambulance personnel, 150 administration and service workers, and 35 workers in prevention.^[\[92\]](#cite_note-92)^ The brigade began as the Copenhagen Royal Fire Brigade on 9 July 1687 under King Christian V. After the passing of the Copenhagen Fire Act on 18 May 1868, on 1 August 1870 the Copenhagen Fire Brigade became a municipal institution in its own right.^[\[93\]](#cite_note-93)^ The fire department has its headquarters in the [Copenhagen Central Fire Station](/wiki/Copenhagen_Central_Fire_Station "Copenhagen Central Fire Station") which was designed by [Ludvig Fenger](/wiki/Ludvig_Fenger "Ludvig Fenger") in the [Historicist](/wiki/Historicism_(art) "Historicism (art)") style and inaugurated in 1892.^[\[94\]](#cite_note-94)^{#cite_ref-94}

### Environmental planning {#Environmental_planning}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen&action=edit&section=19 "Edit section: Environmental planning")\]  
Main article: [Energy in Denmark](/wiki/Energy_in_Denmark "Energy in Denmark")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/European_Environment_Agency%2C_Copenhagen.jpg/220px-European_Environment_Agency%2C_Copenhagen.jpg)](/wiki/File:European_Environment_Agency,_Copenhagen.jpg) The [European Environment Agency](/wiki/European_Environment_Agency "European Environment Agency") on [Kongens Nytorv](/wiki/Kongens_Nytorv "Kongens Nytorv")

Copenhagen is recognised as one of the most environmentally friendly cities in the world.^[\[95\]](#cite_note-95)^ As a result of its commitment to high environmental standards, Copenhagen has been praised for its [green economy](/wiki/Green_economy "Green economy"), ranked as the top green city for the second time in the 2014 *Global Green Economy Index (GGEI)* .^[\[96\]](#cite_note-ggei-96)^^[\[97\]](#cite_note-97)^ In 2001 a large offshore [wind farm](/wiki/Wind_farm "Wind farm") was built just off the coast of Copenhagen at [Middelgrunden](/wiki/Middelgrunden_wind_farm "Middelgrunden wind farm"). It produces about 4% of the city's energy.^[\[98\]](#cite_note-98)^ Years of substantial investment in [sewage treatment](/wiki/Sewage_treatment "Sewage treatment") have improved [water quality](/wiki/Water_quality "Water quality") in the harbour to an extent that the [Inner Harbour](/wiki/Inner_Harbour,_Copenhagen "Inner Harbour, Copenhagen") can be used for swimming with facilities at a number of locations.^[\[99\]](#cite_note-99)^{#cite_ref-99}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Copenhagen_view_from_North_port_20090818_41.JPG/200px-Copenhagen_view_from_North_port_20090818_41.JPG)](/wiki/File:Copenhagen_view_from_North_port_20090818_41.JPG) Middelgrunden offshore wind farm

Copenhagen aims to be [carbon-neutral](/wiki/Carbon-neutral "Carbon-neutral") by 2025. Commercial and residential buildings are to reduce electricity consumption by 20 per cent and 10 per cent respectively, and total heat consumption is to fall by 20 per cent by 2025. Renewable energy features such as solar panels are becoming increasingly common in the newest buildings in Copenhagen. [District heating](/wiki/District_heating "District heating") will be carbon-neutral by 2025, by waste [incineration](/wiki/Incineration "Incineration") and biomass. New buildings must now be constructed according to Low Energy Class ratings and in 2020 near net-zero energy buildings. By 2025, 75% of trips should be made on foot, by bike, or by using public transit. The city plans that 20--30% of cars will run on electricity or [biofuel](/wiki/Biofuel "Biofuel") by 2025. The investment is estimated at $472 million public funds and $4.78 billion private funds.^[\[100\]](#cite_note-100)^{#cite_ref-100}

The city's urban planning authorities continue to take full account of these priorities. Special attention is given both to climate issues and efforts to ensure maximum application of [low-energy standards](/wiki/Low-energy_house "Low-energy house"). Priorities include [sustainable drainage systems](/wiki/Sustainable_drainage_system "Sustainable drainage system"),^[\[101\]](#cite_note-101)^ [recycling rainwater](/wiki/Water_conservation "Water conservation"), [green roofs](/wiki/Green_roof "Green roof") and efficient [waste management](/wiki/Waste_management "Waste management") solutions. In city planning, streets and squares are to be designed to encourage cycling and walking rather than driving.^[\[102\]](#cite_note-102)^{#cite_ref-102}

{#cite_ref-countryoforigin_104-0}

Copenhagen is the most populous city in Denmark and one of the [most populous in the Nordic countries](/wiki/List_of_urban_areas_in_the_Nordic_countries "List of urban areas in the Nordic countries"). For statistical purposes, [Statistics Denmark](/wiki/Statistics_Denmark "Statistics Denmark") considers the [City of Copenhagen](/wiki/City_of_Copenhagen "City of Copenhagen") (*Byen København*) to consist of the [Municipality of Copenhagen](/wiki/Copenhagen_Municipality "Copenhagen Municipality") plus three adjacent municipalities: [Dragør](/wiki/Drag%C3%B8r_Municipality "Dragør Municipality"), [Frederiksberg](/wiki/Frederiksberg_Municipality "Frederiksberg Municipality"), and [Tårnby](/wiki/T%C3%A5rnby_Municipality "Tårnby Municipality").^[\[105\]](#cite_note-dst.dk-105)^ Their combined population stands at 763,908 (as of December 2016^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen&action=edit)^).^[\[10\]](#cite_note-ReferenceA-10)^{#cite_ref-ReferenceA_10-1}

The Municipality of Copenhagen is by far the most populous [in the country](/wiki/Municipalities_of_Denmark "Municipalities of Denmark") and one of the [most populous Nordic municipalities](/wiki/List_of_the_most_populated_municipalities_in_the_Nordic_countries "List of the most populated municipalities in the Nordic countries") with 644,431 inhabitants (as of 2022).^[\[6\]](#cite_note-pop1-6)^ There was a demographic boom in the 1990s and first decades of the 21st century, largely due to [immigration to Denmark](/wiki/Immigration_to_Denmark "Immigration to Denmark"). According to figures from the first quarter of 2022, 73.7% of the municipality's population was of [Danish](/wiki/Danes "Danes") descent,^[\[104\]](#cite_note-countryoforigin-104)^ defined as having at least one parent who was born in Denmark and has Danish citizenship. Much of the remaining 26.3% were of a foreign background, defined as immigrants (20.3%) or descendants of recent immigrants (6%).^[\[104\]](#cite_note-countryoforigin-104)^ There are no official statistics on [ethnic groups](/wiki/Ethnic_group "Ethnic group"). The adjacent table shows the most common countries of origin of Copenhagen residents. Largest foreign groups are Pakistanis (1.3%), Turks (1.2%), Iraqis (1.1%), Germans (1.0%) and Poles (1.0%).{#cite_ref-countryoforigin_104-2}

According to Statistics Denmark, Copenhagen's urban area has a larger population of 1,280,371 (as of 1 January 2016^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen&action=edit)^).^[\[6\]](#cite_note-pop1-6)^ The urban area consists of the municipalities of Copenhagen and Frederiksberg plus 16 of the 20 municipalities of the former counties [Copenhagen](/wiki/Copenhagen_County "Copenhagen County") and [Roskilde](/wiki/Roskilde_County "Roskilde County"), though five of them only partially.^[\[84\]](#cite_note-urban-84)^ [Metropolitan Copenhagen](/wiki/Copenhagen_metropolitan_area "Copenhagen metropolitan area") has a total of 2,016,285 inhabitants (as of 2016^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen&action=edit)^).^[\[6\]](#cite_note-pop1-6)^ The area of Metropolitan Copenhagen is defined by the [Finger Plan](/wiki/Finger_Plan "Finger Plan").^[\[106\]](#cite_note-fingerplan-106)^ Since the opening of the [Øresund Bridge](/wiki/%C3%98resund_Bridge "Øresund Bridge") in 2000, commuting between [Zealand](/wiki/Zealand "Zealand") and [Scania](/wiki/Scania "Scania") in Sweden has increased rapidly, leading to a wider, integrated area. Known as the Øresund Region, it has 4.1 million inhabitants---of whom 2.7 million (August 2021) live in the Danish part of the region.^[\[107\]](#cite_note-107)^

### Religion {#Religion}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen&action=edit&section=21 "Edit section: Religion")\]  
See also: [List of churches in Copenhagen](/wiki/List_of_churches_in_Copenhagen "List of churches in Copenhagen") and [Religion in Denmark](/wiki/Religion_in_Denmark "Religion in Denmark")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/Vor_Frue_Kirke_Copenhagen.jpg/220px-Vor_Frue_Kirke_Copenhagen.jpg)](/wiki/File:Vor_Frue_Kirke_Copenhagen.jpg) The [Church of Our Lady](/wiki/Church_of_Our_Lady_(Copenhagen) "Church of Our Lady (Copenhagen)"), situated on [Frue Plads](/wiki/Frue_Plads "Frue Plads")

A majority (56.9%) of those living in Copenhagen are members of the Lutheran [Church of Denmark](/wiki/Church_of_Denmark "Church of Denmark") which is 0.6% lower than one year earlier according to 2019 figures.^[\[109\]](#cite_note-109)^ The National Cathedral, the [Church of Our Lady](/wiki/Church_of_Our_Lady_(Copenhagen) "Church of Our Lady (Copenhagen)"), is one of the dozens of churches in Copenhagen. There are also several other Christian communities in the city, of which the largest is [Roman Catholic](/wiki/Roman_Catholic "Roman Catholic").^[\[110\]](#cite_note-110)^{#cite_ref-110}

Foreign migration to Copenhagen, rising over the last three decades, has contributed to increasing religious diversity; the [Grand Mosque of Copenhagen](/wiki/Grand_Mosque_of_Copenhagen "Grand Mosque of Copenhagen"), the first in Denmark, opened in 2014.^[\[111\]](#cite_note-111)^ [Islam](/wiki/Islam "Islam") is the second largest religion in Copenhagen, accounting for approximately 10% of the population.^[\[112\]](#cite_note-Nydell-112)^^[\[113\]](#cite_note-Farmer_2010-113)^^[\[114\]](#cite_note-Micklethwait-114)^ While there are no official statistics, a significant portion of the estimated 175,000--200,000 Muslims in the country live in the Copenhagen urban area, with the highest concentration in [Nørrebro](/wiki/N%C3%B8rrebro "Nørrebro") and the Vestegnen.^[\[115\]](#cite_note-osf-115)^ There are also some 7,000 Jews in Denmark, most of them in the Copenhagen area where there are several synagogues.^[\[116\]](#cite_note-116)^ It has a membership of 1,800 members.^[\[117\]](#cite_note-NAME-117)^ There is a long history of Jews in the city, and the first synagogue in Copenhagen was built in 1684.^[\[118\]](#cite_note-bh.org.il-118)^ Today, the history of the Jews of Denmark can be explored at the [Danish Jewish Museum](/wiki/Danish_Jewish_Museum "Danish Jewish Museum") in Copenhagen.{#cite_ref-bh.org.il_118-0}  

### Quality of living {#Quality_of_living}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen&action=edit&section=22 "Edit section: Quality of living")\]

For a number of years, Copenhagen has ranked high in international surveys for its [quality of life](/wiki/Quality_of_life "Quality of life"). Its stable economy together with its education services and level of social safety make it attractive for locals and visitors alike. Although it is one of the world's most expensive cities, it is also one of the most liveable with its public transport, facilities for cyclists and its environmental policies.^[\[119\]](#cite_note-119)^ In elevating Copenhagen to "most liveable city" in 2013, *[Monocle](/wiki/Monocle_(media_company) "Monocle (media company)")* pointed to its open spaces, increasing activity on the streets, city planning in favour of cyclists and pedestrians, and features to encourage inhabitants to enjoy city life with an emphasis on community, culture and cuisine.^[\[120\]](#cite_note-120)^ The city is voted 2024 second most liveable city by [Economist Intelligence Unit](/wiki/Economist_Intelligence_Unit "Economist Intelligence Unit").^[\[121\]](#cite_note-121)^ Other sources have ranked Copenhagen high for its business environment, accessibility, restaurants and environmental planning.^[\[122\]](#cite_note-122)^ However, Copenhagen ranks only 39th for student friendliness in 2012. Despite a top score for quality of living, its scores were low for employer activity and affordability.^[\[123\]](#cite_note-123)^{#cite_ref-123}  

Economy {#Economy}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen&action=edit&section=23 "Edit section: Economy")\]

Copenhagen is the major economic and [financial centre](/wiki/Financial_centre "Financial centre") of Denmark. The city's economy is based largely on services and commerce. Statistics for 2010 show that the vast majority of the 350,000 workers in Copenhagen are employed in the [service sector](/wiki/Service_sector "Service sector"), especially transport and communications, trade, and finance, while less than 10,000 work in the manufacturing industries. The [public sector](/wiki/Public_sector "Public sector") workforce is around 110,000, including education and healthcare.^[\[124\]](#cite_note-124)^ From 2006 to 2011, the economy grew by 2.5% in Copenhagen, while it fell by some 4% in the rest of Denmark.^[\[125\]](#cite_note-125)^ In 2017, the wider [Capital Region of Denmark](/wiki/Capital_Region_of_Denmark "Capital Region of Denmark") had a gross domestic product (GDP) of €120 billion, and the 15th largest [GDP per capita](/wiki/GDP_per_capita "GDP per capita") of regions in the European Union.^[\[126\]](#cite_note-126)^ As of Copenhagen Green Economy Leader Report made by [London School of Economics and Political Science](/wiki/London_School_of_Economics "London School of Economics") -- Copenhagen is widely recognised as a leader in the global green economy. The Copenhagen region accounts for almost 40% of Denmark's output and has enjoyed long-term stable growth. At a national level, Danish GDP per capita is ranked among the top 10 countries in the world. At the same time, the city's growth has been delivered while improving environmental performance and transitioning to a low-carbon economy.{#cite_ref-126}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Krystallen_%28Nykredit%29.jpg/170px-Krystallen_%28Nykredit%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Krystallen_(Nykredit).jpg) [The Crystal](/wiki/The_Crystal,_Copenhagen "The Crystal, Copenhagen"), headquarters of Nykredit bank

Several financial institutions and banks have headquarters in Copenhagen, including [Alm. Brand](/wiki/Alm._Brand "Alm. Brand"), [Danske Bank](/wiki/Danske_Bank "Danske Bank"), [Nykredit](/wiki/Nykredit "Nykredit") and [Nordea Bank Danmark](/wiki/Nordea_Bank_Danmark "Nordea Bank Danmark"). The [Copenhagen Stock Exchange](/wiki/Copenhagen_Stock_Exchange "Copenhagen Stock Exchange") (CSE) was founded in 1620 and is now owned by [Nasdaq, Inc.](/wiki/Nasdaq,_Inc. "Nasdaq, Inc.") Copenhagen is also home to a number of international companies including [A.P. Møller-Mærsk](/wiki/Maersk "Maersk"), [Novo Nordisk](/wiki/Novo_Nordisk "Novo Nordisk"), [Carlsberg](/wiki/Carlsberg_Group "Carlsberg Group") and [Novozymes](/wiki/Novozymes "Novozymes").^[\[127\]](#cite_note-127)^ City authorities have encouraged the development of [business clusters](/wiki/Business_cluster "Business cluster") in several innovative sectors, which include information technology, [biotechnology](/wiki/Biotechnology "Biotechnology"), [pharmaceuticals](/wiki/Pharmaceuticals "Pharmaceuticals"), [clean technology](/wiki/Clean_technology "Clean technology") and [smart city](/wiki/Smart_city "Smart city") solutions.^[\[128\]](#cite_note-128)^^[\[129\]](#cite_note-129)^{#cite_ref-129}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Ferring_Neroport_Orestad_20100810_0179F_%288370660268%29.jpg/220px-Ferring_Neroport_Orestad_20100810_0179F_%288370660268%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ferring_Neroport_Orestad_20100810_0179F_(8370660268).jpg) Scandinavian headquarters for the [Swiss](/wiki/Switzerland "Switzerland") pharmaceutical company [Ferring Pharmaceuticals](/wiki/Ferring_Pharmaceuticals "Ferring Pharmaceuticals")

[Life science](/wiki/Biology "Biology") is a key sector with extensive [research and development](/wiki/Research_and_development "Research and development") activities. [Medicon Valley](/wiki/Medicon_Valley "Medicon Valley") is a leading bi-national life sciences cluster in Europe, spanning the Øresund Region. Copenhagen is rich in companies and institutions with a focus on [research and development](/wiki/Research_and_development "Research and development") within the field of biotechnology,^[\[130\]](#cite_note-130)^ and the Medicon Valley initiative aims to strengthen this position and to promote cooperation between companies and academia. Many major Danish companies like Novo Nordisk and [Lundbeck](/wiki/Lundbeck "Lundbeck"), both of which are among the [50 largest pharmaceutical and biotech companies in the world](/wiki/List_of_pharmaceutical_companies "List of pharmaceutical companies"), are located in this business cluster.^[\[131\]](#cite_note-usatoday-131)^{#cite_ref-usatoday_131-0}

Shipping is another important sector with Maersk, the world's largest [shipping company](/wiki/List_of_ship_companies "List of ship companies"), having their world headquarters in Copenhagen. The city has an industrial harbour, [Copenhagen Port](/wiki/Copenhagen_Port "Copenhagen Port"). Following decades of stagnation, it has experienced a resurgence since 1990 following a merger with [Malmö](/wiki/Malm%C3%B6 "Malmö") harbour. Both ports are operated by [Copenhagen Malmö Port](/wiki/Copenhagen_Malm%C3%B6_Port "Copenhagen Malmö Port") (CMP). The central location in the Øresund Region allows the ports to act as a hub for freight that is transported onward to the [Baltic countries](/wiki/Baltic_countries "Baltic countries"). CMP annually receives about 8,000 ships and handled some 148,000 [TEU](/wiki/Twenty-foot_equivalent_unit "Twenty-foot equivalent unit") in 2012.^[\[132\]](#cite_note-132)^{#cite_ref-132}

Copenhagen has some of the highest gross wages in the world.^[\[133\]](#cite_note-133)^ High taxes mean that wages are reduced after mandatory deduction. A *beneficial researcher scheme* with low taxation of foreign specialists has made Denmark an attractive location for [foreign labour](/wiki/Immigration "Immigration"). It is, however, also among the most expensive cities in Europe.^[\[134\]](#cite_note-134)^^[\[135\]](#cite_note-135)^{#cite_ref-135}

Denmark's [Flexicurity](/wiki/Flexicurity "Flexicurity") model features some of the most flexible hiring and firing legislation in Europe, providing attractive conditions for [foreign investment](/wiki/Foreign_direct_investment "Foreign direct investment") and international companies looking to locate in Copenhagen.^[\[136\]](#cite_note-136)^ In [Dansk Industri](/wiki/Dansk_Industri "Dansk Industri")'s 2013 survey of employment factors in the ninety-six municipalities of Denmark, Copenhagen came in first place for educational qualifications and for the development of private companies in recent years, but fell to 86th place in local companies' assessment of the employment climate. The survey revealed considerable dissatisfaction in the level of dialogue companies enjoyed with the municipal authorities.^[\[137\]](#cite_note-137)^{#cite_ref-137}  

### Tourism {#Tourism}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen&action=edit&section=24 "Edit section: Tourism")\]  
See also: [Tourism in Denmark](/wiki/Tourism_in_Denmark "Tourism in Denmark")

Tourism is a major contributor to Copenhagen's economy, attracting visitors due to the city's harbour, cultural attractions and award-winning restaurants. Since 2009, Copenhagen has been one of the fastest growing metropolitan destinations in Europe.^[\[138\]](#cite_note-tourismstats-138)^ Hotel capacity in the city is growing significantly. From 2009 to 2013, it experienced a 42% growth in international bed nights (total number of nights spent by tourists), tallying a rise of nearly 70% for Chinese visitors.^[\[138\]](#cite_note-tourismstats-138)^ The total number of bed nights in the Capital Region surpassed 9 million in 2013, while international bed nights reached 5 million.^[\[138\]](#cite_note-tourismstats-138)^{#cite_ref-tourismstats_138-2}

In 2010, it is estimated that [city break](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/city_break "wikt:city break") tourism contributed to DKK 2 billion in turnover. However, 2010 was an exceptional year for city break tourism and turnover increased with 29% in that one year.^[\[139\]](#cite_note-139)^ 680,000 cruise passengers visited the port in 2015.^[\[140\]](#cite_note-140)^ In 2019 Copenhagen was ranked first among Lonely Planet's top ten cities to visit.^[\[141\]](#cite_note-141)^ In October 2021, Copenhagen was shortlisted for the [European Commission](/wiki/European_Commission "European Commission")'s 2022 European Capital of Smart Tourism award along with [Bordeaux](/wiki/Bordeaux "Bordeaux"), [Dublin](/wiki/Dublin "Dublin"), [Florence](/wiki/Florence "Florence"), [Ljubljana](/wiki/Ljubljana "Ljubljana"), [Palma de Mallorca](/wiki/Palma_de_Mallorca "Palma de Mallorca") and [Valencia](/wiki/Valencia "Valencia").^[\[142\]](#cite_note-142)^{#cite_ref-142}  

Cityscape {#Cityscape}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen&action=edit&section=25 "Edit section: Cityscape")\]  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/Copenhagen_skyline.jpg/600px-Copenhagen_skyline.jpg)](/wiki/File:Copenhagen_skyline.jpg "The city skyline features many towers and spires.")  
[](/wiki/File:Copenhagen_skyline.jpg "File:Copenhagen skyline.jpg") The city skyline features many towers and spires.

The city's appearance today is shaped by the key role it has played as a regional centre for centuries. Copenhagen has a multitude of districts, each with its distinctive character and representing its own period. Other distinctive features of Copenhagen include the abundance of water, its many parks, and the [bicycle paths](/wiki/Bike_path "Bike path") that line most streets.^[\[143\]](#cite_note-143)^{#cite_ref-143}  

### Architecture {#Architecture}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen&action=edit&section=26 "Edit section: Architecture")\]
