See also: [Architecture in Copenhagen](/wiki/Architecture_in_Copenhagen "Architecture in Copenhagen"), [Listed buildings in Copenhagen Municipality](/wiki/Listed_buildings_in_Copenhagen_Municipality "Listed buildings in Copenhagen Municipality"), and [List of buildings in and around Copenhagen](/wiki/List_of_buildings_in_and_around_Copenhagen "List of buildings in and around Copenhagen")  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/Nyhavn_copenhagen.jpg/200px-Nyhavn_copenhagen.jpg)](/wiki/File:Nyhavn_copenhagen.jpg)  
[Nyhavn](/wiki/Nyhavn "Nyhavn") is a 17th-century waterfront lined by brightly coloured townhouses.  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Amagertorv_kbh.jpg/200px-Amagertorv_kbh.jpg)](/wiki/File:Amagertorv_kbh.jpg)  
The central square, [Amagertorv](/wiki/Amagertorv "Amagertorv"), dates back to the Middle Ages.  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/N%C3%B8rrebrogade_No_57.jpg/200px-N%C3%B8rrebrogade_No_57.jpg)](/wiki/File:N%C3%B8rrebrogade_No_57.jpg)  
Classic building in Copenhagen from around the 1890s. Areas like [Vesterbro](/wiki/Vesterbro,_Copenhagen "Vesterbro, Copenhagen"), [Nørrebro](/wiki/N%C3%B8rrebro "Nørrebro") and [Østerbro](/wiki/%C3%98sterbro "Østerbro") were developed around 1890.

The oldest section of Copenhagen's [inner city](/wiki/Inner_city "Inner city") is often referred to as *Middelalderbyen* (the [medieval](/wiki/Medieval "Medieval") city).^[\[144\]](#cite_note-144)^ However, the city's most distinctive district is [Frederiksstaden](/wiki/Frederiksstaden "Frederiksstaden"), developed during the reign of [Frederick V](/wiki/Frederick_V_of_Denmark "Frederick V of Denmark"). It has the [Amalienborg](/wiki/Amalienborg "Amalienborg") Palace at its centre and is dominated by the dome of [Frederik's Church](/wiki/Frederik%27s_Church "Frederik's Church") (or the Marble Church) and several elegant 18th-century [Rococo](/wiki/Rococo "Rococo") mansions.^[\[145\]](#cite_note-145)^ The inner city includes [Slotsholmen](/wiki/Slotsholmen "Slotsholmen"), a little island on which [Christiansborg Palace](/wiki/Christiansborg_Palace "Christiansborg Palace") stands and [Christianshavn](/wiki/Christianshavn "Christianshavn") with its canals.^[\[146\]](#cite_note-146)^ [Børsen](/wiki/B%C3%B8rsen "Børsen") on Slotsholmen and [Frederiksborg Palace](/wiki/Frederiksborg_Palace "Frederiksborg Palace") in Hillerød are prominent examples of the [Dutch Renaissance](/wiki/Dutch_Renaissance "Dutch Renaissance") style in Copenhagen. Around the historical city centre lies a band of congenial residential boroughs ([Vesterbro](/wiki/Vesterbro,_Copenhagen "Vesterbro, Copenhagen"), [Inner Nørrebro](/wiki/N%C3%B8rrebro "Nørrebro"), [Inner Østerbro](/wiki/Indre_%C3%98sterbro "Indre Østerbro")) dating mainly from late 19th century. They were built outside the old ramparts when the city was finally allowed to expand beyond its fortifications.^[\[147\]](#cite_note-147)^{#cite_ref-147}

Sometimes referred to as "the City of Spires", Copenhagen is known for its horizontal skyline, broken only by the spires and towers of its churches and castles. Most characteristic of all is the [Baroque](/wiki/Baroque "Baroque") spire of the [Church of Our Saviour](/wiki/Church_of_Our_Saviour,_Copenhagen "Church of Our Saviour, Copenhagen") with its narrowing external spiral stairway that visitors can climb to the top.^[\[148\]](#cite_note-148)^ Other important spires are those of [Christiansborg Palace](/wiki/Christiansborg_Palace "Christiansborg Palace"), the [City Hall](/wiki/Copenhagen_City_Hall "Copenhagen City Hall") and the former Church of St. Nikolaj that now houses a [modern art](/wiki/Modern_art "Modern art") venue. Not quite so high are the [Renaissance](/wiki/Renaissance_architecture "Renaissance architecture") spires of [Rosenborg Castle](/wiki/Rosenborg_Castle "Rosenborg Castle") and the "dragon spire" of [Christian IV's former stock exchange](/wiki/B%C3%B8rsen "Børsen"), so named because it resembles the intertwined tails of four dragons.^[\[149\]](#cite_note-149)^{#cite_ref-149}

Copenhagen is recognised globally as an exemplar of best practice [urban planning](/wiki/Urban_planning "Urban planning").^[\[150\]](#cite_note-150)^ Its thriving mixed use city centre is defined by striking contemporary architecture, engaging public spaces and an abundance of human activity. These design outcomes have been deliberately achieved through careful replanning in the second half of the 20th century.{#cite_ref-150}

Recent years have seen a boom in modern architecture in Copenhagen^[\[151\]](#cite_note-baumeister1-151)^ both for [Danish architecture](/wiki/Architecture_of_Denmark "Architecture of Denmark") and for works by international architects. For a few hundred years, virtually no foreign architects had worked in Copenhagen, but since the turn of the millennium the city and its immediate surroundings have seen buildings and projects designed by top international architects. British design magazine *[Monocle](/wiki/Monocle_(2007_magazine) "Monocle (2007 magazine)")* named Copenhagen the *World's best design city 2008* .^[\[152\]](#cite_note-152)^{#cite_ref-152}

Copenhagen's urban development in the first half of the 20th century was heavily influenced by industrialisation. After World War II, Copenhagen Municipality adopted [Fordism](/wiki/Fordism "Fordism") and repurposed its medieval centre to facilitate private automobile infrastructure in response to innovations in transport, trade and communication.^[\[153\]](#cite_note-:0-153)^ Copenhagen's spatial planning in this time frame was characterised by the separation of land uses: an approach which requires residents to travel by car to access facilities of different uses.^[\[154\]](#cite_note-154)^{#cite_ref-154}

The boom in urban development and [modern architecture](/wiki/Modern_architecture "Modern architecture") has brought some changes to the city's skyline. A political majority has decided to keep the historical centre free of high-rise buildings, but several areas will see or have already seen massive urban development. [Ørestad](/wiki/%C3%98restad "Ørestad") now has seen most of the recent development. Located near [Copenhagen Airport](/wiki/Copenhagen_Airport "Copenhagen Airport"), it currently boasts one of the largest malls in Scandinavia and a variety of office and residential buildings as well as the [IT University](/wiki/IT_University_of_Copenhagen "IT University of Copenhagen") and a high school.^[\[155\]](#cite_note-155)^{#cite_ref-155}  

### Parks, gardens and zoo {#Parks.2C_gardens_and_zoo}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen&action=edit&section=27 "Edit section: Parks, gardens and zoo")\]  
Main article: [Parks and open spaces in Copenhagen](/wiki/Parks_and_open_spaces_in_Copenhagen "Parks and open spaces in Copenhagen")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/Rosenborg_-_park_setting.jpg/220px-Rosenborg_-_park_setting.jpg)](/wiki/File:Rosenborg_-_park_setting.jpg) Rosenborg Castle and park in central Copenhagen

Copenhagen is a green city with many parks, both large and small. [King's Garden](/wiki/Rosenborg_Castle_Gardens "Rosenborg Castle Gardens") (**Kongens Have** ), the garden of [Rosenborg Castle](/wiki/Rosenborg_Castle "Rosenborg Castle"), is the oldest and most frequented of them all.^[\[156\]](#cite_note-www1-156)^ It was [Christian IV](/wiki/Christian_IV_of_Denmark "Christian IV of Denmark") who first developed its landscaping in 1606. Every year it sees more than 2.5 million visitors^[\[157\]](#cite_note-157)^ and in the summer months it is packed with sunbathers, picnickers and ballplayers. It serves as a [sculpture garden](/wiki/Sculpture_garden "Sculpture garden") with both a permanent display and temporary exhibits during the summer months.^[\[156\]](#cite_note-www1-156)^ Also located in the city centre are the [Botanical Gardens](/wiki/University_of_Copenhagen_Botanical_Garden "University of Copenhagen Botanical Garden") noted for their large complex of 19th-century greenhouses donated by [Carlsberg](/wiki/Carlsberg_Group "Carlsberg Group") founder [J. C. Jacobsen](/wiki/J._C._Jacobsen "J. C. Jacobsen").^[\[158\]](#cite_note-158)^ [Fælledparken](/wiki/F%C3%A6lledparken "Fælledparken") at 58 ha (140 acres) is the largest park in Copenhagen.^[\[159\]](#cite_note-159)^{#cite_ref-159}

It is popular for sports fixtures and hosts several annual events including a free opera concert at the opening of the opera season, other open-air concerts, [carnival](/wiki/Carnival "Carnival") and Labour Day celebrations, and the [Copenhagen Historic Grand Prix](/wiki/Copenhagen_Historic_Grand_Prix "Copenhagen Historic Grand Prix"), a race for [antique cars](/wiki/Antique_car "Antique car"). A historical [green space](/wiki/Green_belt "Green belt") in the northeastern part of the city is [Kastellet](/wiki/Kastellet,_Copenhagen "Kastellet, Copenhagen"), a well-preserved Renaissance [citadel](/wiki/Citadel "Citadel") that now serves mainly as a park.^[\[160\]](#cite_note-160)^ Another popular park is the [Frederiksberg Gardens](/wiki/Frederiksberg_Gardens "Frederiksberg Gardens"), a 32-hectare [romantic](/wiki/Romanticism "Romanticism") [landscape park](/wiki/Landscape_garden "Landscape garden"). It houses a colony of tame [grey herons](/wiki/Grey_heron "Grey heron") and other [waterfowl](/wiki/Waterfowl "Waterfowl").^[\[161\]](#cite_note-161)^ The park offers views of the elephants and the elephant house designed by world-famous British architect [Norman Foster](/wiki/Norman_Foster_(architect) "Norman Foster (architect)") of the adjacent [Copenhagen Zoo](/wiki/Copenhagen_Zoo "Copenhagen Zoo").^[\[162\]](#cite_note-162)^ [Langelinie](/wiki/Langelinie "Langelinie"), a park and promenade along the inner [Øresund](/wiki/%C3%98resund "Øresund") coast, is home to one of Copenhagen's most-visited tourist attractions, the [Little Mermaid statue](/wiki/The_Little_Mermaid_(statue) "The Little Mermaid (statue)").^[\[163\]](#cite_note-163)^{#cite_ref-163}

In Copenhagen, many [cemeteries](/wiki/Cemetery "Cemetery") double as parks, though only for the more quiet activities such as sunbathing, reading and meditation. [Assistens Cemetery](/wiki/Assistens_Cemetery_(Copenhagen) "Assistens Cemetery (Copenhagen)"), the burial place of [Hans Christian Andersen](/wiki/Hans_Christian_Andersen "Hans Christian Andersen"), is an important green space for the district of [Inner Nørrebro](/wiki/N%C3%B8rrebro "Nørrebro") and a Copenhagen institution. The lesser known [Vestre Kirkegaard](/wiki/Vestre_Cemetery "Vestre Cemetery") is the largest cemetery in Denmark (54 ha (130 acres)) and offers a maze of dense groves, open lawns, winding paths, hedges, overgrown tombs, monuments, tree-lined avenues, lakes and other [garden features](/wiki/List_of_garden_features "List of garden features").^[\[164\]](#cite_note-164)^{#cite_ref-164}

It is official municipal policy in Copenhagen that by 2015 all citizens must be able to reach a park or beach on foot in less than 15 minutes.^[\[165\]](#cite_note-165)^ In line with this policy, several new parks, including the innovative [Superkilen](/wiki/Superkilen "Superkilen") in the Nørrebro district, have been completed or are under development in areas lacking green spaces.^[\[166\]](#cite_note-166)^{#cite_ref-166}  

### Landmarks by district {#Landmarks_by_district}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen&action=edit&section=28 "Edit section: Landmarks by district")\]  

#### Indre By {#Indre_By}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen&action=edit&section=29 "Edit section: Indre By")\]

The historic centre of the city, [Indre By](/wiki/Indre_By "Indre By") or the Inner City, features many of Copenhagen's most popular monuments and attractions. The area known as [Frederiksstaden](/wiki/Frederiksstaden "Frederiksstaden"), developed by [Frederik V](/wiki/Frederik_V_of_Denmark "Frederik V of Denmark") in the second half of the 18th century in the [Rococo](/wiki/Rococo "Rococo") style, has the four mansions of [Amalienborg](/wiki/Amalienborg "Amalienborg"), the royal residence, and the wide-domed [Marble Church](/wiki/Frederik%27s_Church "Frederik's Church") at its centre.^[\[167\]](#cite_note-167)^ Directly across the water from Amalienborg, the 21st-century [Copenhagen Opera House](/wiki/Copenhagen_Opera_House "Copenhagen Opera House") stands on the island of [Holmen](/wiki/Holmen,_Copenhagen "Holmen, Copenhagen").^[\[168\]](#cite_note-168)^ To the south of Frederiksstaden, the [Nyhavn](/wiki/Nyhavn "Nyhavn") canal is lined with colourful houses from the 17th and 18th centuries, many now with lively restaurants and bars.^[\[169\]](#cite_note-169)^ The canal runs from the harbour front to the spacious square of [Kongens Nytorv](/wiki/Kongens_Nytorv "Kongens Nytorv") which was laid out by [Christian V](/wiki/Christian_V "Christian V") in 1670. Important buildings include [Charlottenborg Palace](/wiki/Charlottenborg_Palace "Charlottenborg Palace"), famous for its art exhibitions, the [Thott Palace](/wiki/Embassy_of_France,_Copenhagen "Embassy of France, Copenhagen") (now the French embassy), the [Royal Danish Theatre](/wiki/Royal_Danish_Theatre "Royal Danish Theatre") and the [Hotel D'Angleterre](/wiki/Hotel_D%27Angleterre "Hotel D'Angleterre"), dated to 1755.^[\[170\]](#cite_note-170)^ Other landmarks in Indre By include the parliament building of [Christiansborg](/wiki/Christiansborg "Christiansborg"), the [City Hall](/wiki/Copenhagen_City_Hall "Copenhagen City Hall") and [Rundetårn](/wiki/Rundet%C3%A5rn "Rundetårn"), originally an observatory. There are also several museums in the area including [Thorvaldsen Museum](/wiki/Thorvaldsen_Museum "Thorvaldsen Museum") dedicated to the 18th-century sculptor [Bertel Thorvaldsen](/wiki/Bertel_Thorvaldsen "Bertel Thorvaldsen").^[\[171\]](#cite_note-171)^ Closed to traffic since 1964, [Strøget](/wiki/Str%C3%B8get "Strøget"), one of the world's oldest and longest pedestrian streets, runs the 3.2 km (2.0 mi) from Rådhuspladsen to Kongens Nytorv. With its speciality shops, cafés, restaurants, and [buskers](/wiki/Buskers "Buskers"), it is always full of life and includes the old squares of [Gammel Torv](/wiki/Gammel_Torv "Gammel Torv") and [Amagertorv](/wiki/Amagertorv "Amagertorv"), each with a fountain.^[\[172\]](#cite_note-172)^ [Rosenborg Castle](/wiki/Rosenborg_Castle "Rosenborg Castle") on [Øster Voldgade](/wiki/%C3%98ster_Voldgade "Øster Voldgade") was built by Christian IV in 1606 as a summer residence in the [Renaissance](/wiki/Renaissance_architecture "Renaissance architecture") style. It houses the Danish crown jewels and [crown regalia](/wiki/Danish_Crown_Regalia "Danish Crown Regalia"), the [coronation throne](/wiki/Throne_Chair_of_Denmark "Throne Chair of Denmark") and tapestries illustrating Christian V's victories in the [Scanian War](/wiki/Scanian_War "Scanian War").^[\[173\]](#cite_note-173)^{#cite_ref-173}  

#### Christianshavn {#Christianshavn}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen&action=edit&section=30 "Edit section: Christianshavn")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Christianshavns_Kanal_boats.jpg/220px-Christianshavns_Kanal_boats.jpg)](/wiki/File:Christianshavns_Kanal_boats.jpg) Christianshavn Canal

[Christianshavn](/wiki/Christianshavn "Christianshavn") lies to the southeast of [Indre By](/wiki/Indre_By "Indre By") on the other side of the harbour. The area was developed by [Christian IV](/wiki/Christian_IV_of_Denmark "Christian IV of Denmark") in the early 17th century. Impressed by the city of [Amsterdam](/wiki/Amsterdam "Amsterdam"), he employed Dutch architects to create canals within its [ramparts](/wiki/Christianshavns_Vold "Christianshavns Vold") which are still well preserved today.^[\[25\]](#cite_note-kher-25)^ The canals themselves, branching off the central [Christianshavn Canal](/wiki/Christianshavns_Kanal "Christianshavns Kanal") and lined with house boats and pleasure craft are one of the area's attractions.^[\[174\]](#cite_note-174)^ Another interesting feature is [Freetown Christiania](/wiki/Freetown_Christiania "Freetown Christiania"), a fairly large area which was initially occupied by squatters during student unrest in 1971. Today it still maintains a measure of autonomy. The inhabitants openly sell drugs on "Pusher Street" as well as their arts and crafts. Other buildings of interest in Christianshavn include the [Church of Our Saviour](/wiki/Church_of_Our_Saviour,_Copenhagen "Church of Our Saviour, Copenhagen") with its spiralling steeple and the magnificent Rococo [Christian's Church](/wiki/Christian%27s_Church,_Copenhagen "Christian's Church, Copenhagen"). Once a warehouse, the [North Atlantic House](/wiki/North_Atlantic_House "North Atlantic House") now displays culture from Iceland and Greenland and houses the [Noma](/wiki/Noma_(restaurant) "Noma (restaurant)") restaurant, known for its Nordic cuisine.^[\[175\]](#cite_note-175)^^[\[176\]](#cite_note-176)^{#cite_ref-176}  

#### Vesterbro {#Vesterbro}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen&action=edit&section=31 "Edit section: Vesterbro")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/Halmtorvet_seen_from_%C3%98ksnehallen.jpg/220px-Halmtorvet_seen_from_%C3%98ksnehallen.jpg)](/wiki/File:Halmtorvet_seen_from_%C3%98ksnehallen.jpg) Halmtorvet in Vesterbro

[Vesterbro](/wiki/Vesterbro,_Copenhagen "Vesterbro, Copenhagen"), to the southwest of Indre By, begins with the [Tivoli Gardens](/wiki/Tivoli_Gardens "Tivoli Gardens"), the city's top tourist attraction with its fairground atmosphere, its [Pantomime Theatre](/wiki/Pantomimeteatret "Pantomimeteatret"), its [Concert Hall](/wiki/Tivolis_Koncertsal "Tivolis Koncertsal") and its many rides and restaurants.^[\[177\]](#cite_note-177)^ The [Carlsberg](/wiki/Carlsberg_(district) "Carlsberg (district)") neighbourhood has some interesting vestiges of the old brewery of the same name including the [Elephant Gate](/wiki/Elephant_Gate_and_Tower,_Carlsberg "Elephant Gate and Tower, Carlsberg") and the [Ny Carlsberg Brewhouse](/wiki/Ny_Carlsberg_Brewhouse "Ny Carlsberg Brewhouse").^[\[178\]](#cite_note-178)^ The [Tycho Brahe Planetarium](/wiki/Tycho_Brahe_Planetarium "Tycho Brahe Planetarium") is located on the edge of [Skt. Jørgens Sø](/wiki/The_Lakes,_Copenhagen "The Lakes, Copenhagen"), one of the Copenhagen lakes.^[\[179\]](#cite_note-179)^ [Halmtorvet](/wiki/Halmtorvet "Halmtorvet"), the old hay market behind the [Central Station](/wiki/Copenhagen_Central_Station "Copenhagen Central Station"), is an increasingly popular area with its cafés and restaurants. The former cattle market Øksnehallen has been converted into a modern exhibition centre for art and photography.^[\[180\]](#cite_note-180)^ [Radisson Blu Royal Hotel](/wiki/Radisson_Blu_Royal_Hotel "Radisson Blu Royal Hotel"), built by Danish architect and designer [Arne Jacobsen](/wiki/Arne_Jacobsen "Arne Jacobsen") for the airline [Scandinavian Airlines System](/wiki/Scandinavian_Airlines_System "Scandinavian Airlines System") (SAS) between 1956 and 1960 was once the tallest hotel in Denmark with a height of 69.60 m (228.3 ft) and the city's only skyscraper until 1969.^[\[181\]](#cite_note-181)^ Completed in 1908, [Det Ny Teater](/wiki/Det_Ny_Teater "Det Ny Teater") (the New Theatre) located in a passage between [Vesterbrogade](/wiki/Vesterbrogade "Vesterbrogade") and [Gammel Kongevej](/wiki/Gammel_Kongevej "Gammel Kongevej") has become a popular venue for musicals since its reopening in 1994, attracting the largest audiences in the country.^[\[182\]](#cite_note-182)^{#cite_ref-182}  

#### Nørrebro {#N.C3.B8rrebro}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen&action=edit&section=32 "Edit section: Nørrebro")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/N%C3%B8rrebrogade_-_beginning.jpg/220px-N%C3%B8rrebrogade_-_beginning.jpg)](/wiki/File:N%C3%B8rrebrogade_-_beginning.jpg) [Dronning Louises Bro](/wiki/Dronning_Louises_Bro "Dronning Louises Bro") leading into [Nørrebrogade](/wiki/N%C3%B8rrebrogade "Nørrebrogade")

[Nørrebro](/wiki/N%C3%B8rrebro "Nørrebro") to the northwest of the city centre has recently developed from a working-class district into a colourful cosmopolitan area with antique shops, non-Danish food stores and restaurants. Much of the activity is centred on [Sankt Hans Torv](/wiki/Sankt_Hans_Torv "Sankt Hans Torv")^[\[183\]](#cite_note-183)^ and around [Rantzausgade](/wiki/Rantzausgade "Rantzausgade"). Copenhagen's historic cemetery, [Assistens Kirkegård](/wiki/Assistens_Cemetery_(Copenhagen) "Assistens Cemetery (Copenhagen)") halfway up Nørrebrogade, is the resting place of many famous figures including [Søren Kierkegaard](/wiki/S%C3%B8ren_Kierkegaard "Søren Kierkegaard"), [Niels Bohr](/wiki/Niels_Bohr "Niels Bohr"), and [Hans Christian Andersen](/wiki/Hans_Christian_Andersen "Hans Christian Andersen") but is also used by locals as a park and recreation area.^[\[184\]](#cite_note-184)^{#cite_ref-184}  

#### Østerbro {#.C3.98sterbro}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen&action=edit&section=33 "Edit section: Østerbro")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Gefion_Fountain%2C_Copenhagen%2C_Copenhagen.jpg/220px-Gefion_Fountain%2C_Copenhagen%2C_Copenhagen.jpg)](/wiki/File:Gefion_Fountain,_Copenhagen,_Copenhagen.jpg) The Gefion Fountain

Just north of the city centre, [Østerbro](/wiki/%C3%98sterbro "Østerbro") is an upper middle-class district with a number of fine mansions, some now serving as embassies.^[\[185\]](#cite_note-185)^ The district stretches from Nørrebro to the waterfront where *[The Little Mermaid](/wiki/The_Little_Mermaid_(statue) "The Little Mermaid (statue)")* statue can be seen from the promenade known as [Langelinie](/wiki/Langelinie "Langelinie"). Inspired by [Hans Christian Andersen](/wiki/Hans_Christian_Andersen "Hans Christian Andersen")'s fairy tale, it was created by [Edvard Eriksen](/wiki/Edvard_Eriksen "Edvard Eriksen") and unveiled in 1913.^[\[186\]](#cite_note-186)^ Not far from the Little Mermaid, the old [Citadel](/wiki/Kastellet,_Copenhagen "Kastellet, Copenhagen") (*Kastellet* ) can be seen. Built by [Christian IV](/wiki/Christian_IV_of_Denmark "Christian IV of Denmark"), it is one of northern Europe's best preserved fortifications. There is also a windmill in the area.^[\[187\]](#cite_note-187)^ The large [Gefion Fountain](/wiki/Gefion_Fountain "Gefion Fountain") (*Gefionspringvandet*) designed by [Anders Bundgaard](/wiki/Anders_Bundgaard "Anders Bundgaard") and completed in 1908 stands close to the southeast corner of Kastellet. Its figures illustrate a Nordic legend.^[\[188\]](#cite_note-188)^{#cite_ref-188}  

#### Frederiksberg {#Frederiksberg}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen&action=edit&section=34 "Edit section: Frederiksberg")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Frederiksberg_Slot_set_fra_pl%C3%A6nen.jpg/220px-Frederiksberg_Slot_set_fra_pl%C3%A6nen.jpg)](/wiki/File:Frederiksberg_Slot_set_fra_pl%C3%A6nen.jpg) Frederiksberg Palace

[Frederiksberg](/wiki/Frederiksberg "Frederiksberg"), a separate municipality within the [urban area of Copenhagen](/wiki/Urban_area_of_Copenhagen "Urban area of Copenhagen"), lies to the west of Nørrebro and Indre By and north of Vesterbro. Its landmarks include [Copenhagen Zoo](/wiki/Copenhagen_Zoo "Copenhagen Zoo") founded in 1869 with over 250 species from all over the world and [Frederiksberg Palace](/wiki/Frederiksberg_Palace "Frederiksberg Palace") built as a summer residence by [Frederick IV](/wiki/Frederick_IV_of_Denmark "Frederick IV of Denmark") who was inspired by Italian architecture. Now a military academy, it overlooks the extensive landscaped [Frederiksberg Gardens](/wiki/Frederiksberg_Gardens "Frederiksberg Gardens") with its [follies](/wiki/Follies "Follies"), waterfalls, lakes and decorative buildings.^[\[189\]](#cite_note-189)^ The wide tree-lined avenue of [Frederiksberg Allé](/wiki/Frederiksberg_All%C3%A9 "Frederiksberg Allé") connecting [Vesterbrogade](/wiki/Vesterbrogade "Vesterbrogade") with the Frederiksberg Gardens has long been associated with theatres and entertainment. While a number of the earlier theatres are now closed, the [Betty Nansen Theatre](/wiki/Betty_Nansen_Teatret "Betty Nansen Teatret") and Aveny-T are still active.^[\[190\]](#cite_note-190)^{#cite_ref-190}  

#### Amagerbro {#Amagerbro}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen&action=edit&section=35 "Edit section: Amagerbro")\]

Amagerbro (also known as Sønderbro) is the district located immediately south-east of [Christianshavn](/wiki/Christianshavn "Christianshavn") at northernmost [Amager](/wiki/Amager "Amager"). The old city moats and their surrounding parks constitute a clear border between these districts. The main street is [Amagerbrogade](/wiki/Amagerbrogade "Amagerbrogade") which after the harbour bridge [Langebro](/wiki/Langebro "Langebro"), is an extension of [H. C. Andersens Boulevard](/wiki/H._C._Andersens_Boulevard "H. C. Andersens Boulevard") and has a number of various stores and shops as well as restaurants and pubs.^[\[191\]](#cite_note-191)^ Amagerbro was built up during the two first decades of the twentieth century and is the city's southernmost block built area with typically 4--7 floors. Further south follows the Sundbyøster and Sundbyvester districts.^[\[192\]](#cite_note-192)^{#cite_ref-192}  

#### Other districts {#Other_districts}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen&action=edit&section=36 "Edit section: Other districts")\]

Not far from [Copenhagen Airport](/wiki/Copenhagen_Airport "Copenhagen Airport") on the [Kastrup](/wiki/Kastrup "Kastrup") coast, [The Blue Planet](/wiki/National_Aquarium_Denmark "National Aquarium Denmark") completed in March 2013 now houses the national aquarium. With its 53 aquariums, it is the largest facility of its kind in Scandinavia.^[\[193\]](#cite_note-193)^ [Grundtvig's Church](/wiki/Grundtvig%27s_Church "Grundtvig's Church"), located in the northern suburb of [Bispebjerg](/wiki/Bispebjerg "Bispebjerg"), was designed by [P.V. Jensen Klint](/wiki/P.V._Jensen_Klint "P.V. Jensen Klint") and completed in 1940. A rare example of [Expressionist](/wiki/Expressionist_architecture "Expressionist architecture") church architecture, its striking [west façade](/wiki/Westwork "Westwork") is reminiscent of a church organ.^[\[194\]](#cite_note-194)^{#cite_ref-194}  

Culture {#Culture}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen&action=edit&section=37 "Edit section: Culture")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/7/7a/Copenhagen_-_the_little_mermaid_statue_-_2013.jpg/170px-Copenhagen_-_the_little_mermaid_statue_-_2013.jpg)](/wiki/File:Copenhagen_-_the_little_mermaid_statue_-_2013.jpg) *[The Little Mermaid](/wiki/The_Little_Mermaid_(statue) "The Little Mermaid (statue)")* statue, an icon of the city and a popular tourist attraction

Apart from being the national capital, Copenhagen also serves as the cultural hub of Denmark and one of the major hubs in wider Scandinavia. Since the late 1990s, it has undergone a transformation from a modest Scandinavian capital into a metropolitan city of international appeal, in the same league as cities such as [Barcelona](/wiki/Barcelona "Barcelona") and [Amsterdam](/wiki/Amsterdam "Amsterdam").^[\[195\]](#cite_note-195)^ This is a result of huge investments in infrastructure and culture as well as the work of successful new Danish architects, designers and chefs.^[\[151\]](#cite_note-baumeister1-151)^^[\[196\]](#cite_note-iht2007-196)^ [Copenhagen Fashion Week](/wiki/Copenhagen_Fashion_Week "Copenhagen Fashion Week") takes place every year in February and August.^[\[197\]](#cite_note-197)^^[\[198\]](#cite_note-198)^{#cite_ref-198}  

### Museums {#Museums}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen&action=edit&section=38 "Edit section: Museums")\]  
See also: [List of museums in and around Copenhagen](/wiki/List_of_museums_in_and_around_Copenhagen "List of museums in and around Copenhagen")

Copenhagen has a wide array of museums of international standing. The [National Museum](/wiki/National_Museum_of_Denmark "National Museum of Denmark"), *Nationalmuseet*, is Denmark's largest museum of [archaeology](/wiki/Archaeology "Archaeology") and [cultural history](/wiki/Cultural_history "Cultural history"), comprising the histories of Danish and foreign cultures alike.^[\[199\]](#cite_note-199)^ Denmark's [National Gallery](/wiki/Statens_Museum_for_Kunst "Statens Museum for Kunst") (*Statens Museum for Kunst*) is the national art museum with collections dating from the 12th century to the present. In addition to Danish painters, artists represented in the collections include [Rubens](/wiki/Peter_Paul_Rubens "Peter Paul Rubens"), [Rembrandt](/wiki/Rembrandt "Rembrandt"), [Picasso](/wiki/Pablo_Picasso "Pablo Picasso"), [Braque](/wiki/Georges_Braque "Georges Braque"), [Léger](/wiki/Fernand_L%C3%A9ger "Fernand Léger"), [Matisse](/wiki/Henri_Matisse "Henri Matisse"), [Emil Nolde](/wiki/Emil_Nolde "Emil Nolde"), [Olafur Eliasson](/wiki/Olafur_Eliasson "Olafur Eliasson"), [Elmgreen \& Dragset](/wiki/Elmgreen_%26_Dragset "Elmgreen & Dragset"), [Superflex](/wiki/Superflex "Superflex"), and [Jens Haaning](/wiki/Jens_Haaning "Jens Haaning").^[\[200\]](#cite_note-200)^{#cite_ref-200}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Main_entrance%2C_Ny_Carlsberg_Glyptotek.jpg/220px-Main_entrance%2C_Ny_Carlsberg_Glyptotek.jpg)](/wiki/File:Main_entrance,_Ny_Carlsberg_Glyptotek.jpg) Ny Carlsberg Glyptotek art museum

Another important Copenhagen art museum is the [Ny Carlsberg Glyptotek](/wiki/Ny_Carlsberg_Glyptotek "Ny Carlsberg Glyptotek") founded by second generation [Carlsberg](/wiki/Carlsberg_Group "Carlsberg Group") philanthropist [Carl Jacobsen](/wiki/Carl_Jacobsen "Carl Jacobsen") and built around his personal collections. Its main focus is classical [Egyptian](/wiki/Ancient_Egypt "Ancient Egypt"), [Roman](/wiki/Roman_Empire "Roman Empire") and [Greek](/wiki/Ancient_Greece "Ancient Greece") sculptures and antiquities and a collection of [Rodin](/wiki/Auguste_Rodin "Auguste Rodin") sculptures, the largest outside France. Besides its sculpture collections, the museum also holds a comprehensive collection of paintings of [Impressionist](/wiki/Impressionism "Impressionism") and [Post-Impressionist](/wiki/Post-Impressionism "Post-Impressionism") painters such as [Monet](/wiki/Claude_Monet "Claude Monet"), [Renoir](/wiki/Pierre-Auguste_Renoir "Pierre-Auguste Renoir"), [Cézanne](/wiki/Paul_C%C3%A9zanne "Paul Cézanne"), [van Gogh](/wiki/Vincent_van_Gogh "Vincent van Gogh") and [Toulouse-Lautrec](/wiki/Henri_de_Toulouse-Lautrec "Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec") as well as works by the Danish [Golden Age](/wiki/Golden_Age "Golden Age") painters.^[\[201\]](#cite_note-201)^{#cite_ref-201}

[Louisiana](/wiki/Louisiana_Museum_of_Modern_Art "Louisiana Museum of Modern Art") is a [Museum of Modern Art](/wiki/Museum_of_Modern_Art "Museum of Modern Art") situated on the coast just north of Copenhagen. It is located in the middle of a sculpture garden on a cliff overlooking [Øresund](/wiki/%C3%98resund "Øresund"). Its collection of over 3,000 items includes works by [Picasso](/wiki/Picasso "Picasso"), [Giacometti](/wiki/Alberto_Giacometti "Alberto Giacometti") and [Dubuffet](/wiki/Dubuffet "Dubuffet").^[\[202\]](#cite_note-202)^ The [Danish Design Museum](/wiki/Danish_Museum_of_Art_%26_Design "Danish Museum of Art & Design") is housed in the 18th-century former [Frederiks Hospital](/wiki/Frederiks_Hospital "Frederiks Hospital") and displays [Danish design](/wiki/Danish_design "Danish design") as well as international design and crafts.^[\[203\]](#cite_note-203)^{#cite_ref-203}

Other museums include: the [Thorvaldsens Museum](/wiki/Thorvaldsens_Museum "Thorvaldsens Museum"), dedicated to the [oeuvre](/wiki/Work_of_art "Work of art") of romantic Danish sculptor [Bertel Thorvaldsen](/wiki/Bertel_Thorvaldsen "Bertel Thorvaldsen") who lived and worked in Rome;^[\[204\]](#cite_note-204)^ the [Cisternerne](/wiki/Cisternerne "Cisternerne") museum, an exhibition space for contemporary art, located in former [cisterns](/wiki/Cistern "Cistern") that come complete with [stalactites](/wiki/Stalactite "Stalactite") formed by the changing water levels;^[\[205\]](#cite_note-205)^ and the [Ordrupgaard](/wiki/Ordrupgaard "Ordrupgaard") Museum, located just north of Copenhagen, which features 19th-century French and Danish art and is noted for its works by [Paul Gauguin](/wiki/Paul_Gauguin "Paul Gauguin").^[\[206\]](#cite_note-206)^{#cite_ref-206}  

### Entertainment and performing arts {#Entertainment_and_performing_arts}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen&action=edit&section=39 "Edit section: Entertainment and performing arts")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/Copenhagen_Theatre_and_Opera.jpg/220px-Copenhagen_Theatre_and_Opera.jpg)](/wiki/File:Copenhagen_Theatre_and_Opera.jpg) The [Royal Danish Playhouse](/wiki/Royal_Danish_Playhouse "Royal Danish Playhouse") (left) and Opera House (background, right)

The new [Copenhagen Concert Hall](/wiki/Copenhagen_Concert_Hall "Copenhagen Concert Hall") opened in January 2009. Designed by [Jean Nouvel](/wiki/Jean_Nouvel "Jean Nouvel"), it has four halls with the main [auditorium](/wiki/Auditorium "Auditorium") seating 1,800 people. It serves as the home of the [Danish National Symphony Orchestra](/wiki/Danish_National_Symphony_Orchestra "Danish National Symphony Orchestra") and along with the [Walt Disney Concert Hall](/wiki/Walt_Disney_Concert_Hall "Walt Disney Concert Hall") in Los Angeles is the most expensive concert hall ever built.^[\[207\]](#cite_note-207)^ Another important venue for classical music is the [Tivoli Concert Hall](/wiki/Tivoli_Concert_Hall "Tivoli Concert Hall") located in the [Tivoli Gardens](/wiki/Tivoli_Gardens "Tivoli Gardens").^[\[208\]](#cite_note-208)^ Designed by [Henning Larsen](/wiki/Henning_Larsen "Henning Larsen"), the [Copenhagen Opera House](/wiki/Copenhagen_Opera_House "Copenhagen Opera House") (*Operaen*) opened in 2005. It is among the most modern opera houses in the world.^[\[209\]](#cite_note-209)^ The [Royal Danish Theatre](/wiki/Royal_Danish_Theatre "Royal Danish Theatre") also stages opera in addition to its drama productions. It is also home to the [Royal Danish Ballet](/wiki/Royal_Danish_Ballet "Royal Danish Ballet"). Founded in 1748 along with the theatre, it is one of the oldest ballet troupes in Europe, and is noted for its [Bournonville style](/wiki/Bournonville_School "Bournonville School") of ballet.^[\[210\]](#cite_note-210)^{#cite_ref-210}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Royal_Danish_Theatre%2C_Copenhagen.jpg/220px-Royal_Danish_Theatre%2C_Copenhagen.jpg)](/wiki/File:Royal_Danish_Theatre,_Copenhagen.jpg) The Royal Danish Theatre main building

Copenhagen has a significant [jazz](/wiki/Jazz "Jazz") scene that has existed for many years. It developed when a number of American [jazz musicians](/wiki/List_of_jazz_musicians "List of jazz musicians") such as [Ben Webster](/wiki/Ben_Webster "Ben Webster"), [Thad Jones](/wiki/Thad_Jones "Thad Jones"), [Richard Boone](/wiki/Richard_B._Boone "Richard B. Boone"), Ernie Wilkins, [Kenny Drew](/wiki/Kenny_Drew "Kenny Drew"), [Ed Thigpen](/wiki/Ed_Thigpen "Ed Thigpen"), [Bob Rockwell](/wiki/Bob_Rockwell "Bob Rockwell"), [Dexter Gordon](/wiki/Dexter_Gordon "Dexter Gordon"), and others such as [rock guitarist](/wiki/Guitarist "Guitarist") [Link Wray](/wiki/Link_Wray "Link Wray") came to live in Copenhagen during the 1960s. Every year in early July, Copenhagen's streets, squares, parks as well as cafés and concert halls fill up with big and small jazz concerts during the [Copenhagen Jazz Festival](/wiki/Copenhagen_Jazz_Festival "Copenhagen Jazz Festival"). One of Europe's top jazz festivals, the annual event features around 900 concerts at 100 venues with over 200,000 guests from Denmark and around the world.^[\[211\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEO'Brien200520-211)^{#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEO'Brien200520_211-0}

The largest venue for [popular music](/wiki/Popular_music "Popular music") in Copenhagen is [Vega](/wiki/Vega,_Copenhagen "Vega, Copenhagen") in the [Vesterbro](/wiki/Vesterbro,_Copenhagen "Vesterbro, Copenhagen") district. It was chosen as "best concert venue in Europe" by international music magazine *Live* . The venue has three concert halls: the great hall, Store Vega, accommodates audiences of 1,550, the middle hall, Lille Vega, has space for 500 and Ideal Bar Live has a capacity of 250.^[\[212\]](#cite_note-vega-212)^ Every September since 2006, the Festival of Endless Gratitude (FOEG) has taken place in Copenhagen. This festival focuses on [indie](/wiki/Indie_art "Indie art") [counterculture](/wiki/Counterculture "Counterculture"), [experimental pop music](/wiki/Experimental_rock "Experimental rock") and [left field](/wiki/Left_field "Left field") music combined with visual arts exhibitions.^[\[213\]](#cite_note-213)^{#cite_ref-213}

For free entertainment one can stroll along [Strøget](/wiki/Str%C3%B8get "Strøget"), especially between [Nytorv](/wiki/Nytorv "Nytorv") and [Højbro Plads](/wiki/H%C3%B8jbro_Plads "Højbro Plads"), which in the late afternoon and evening is a bit like an impromptu three-ring [circus](/wiki/Circus "Circus") with musicians, [magicians](/wiki/Magic_(illusion) "Magic (illusion)"), [jugglers](/wiki/Juggling "Juggling") and other [street performers](/wiki/Busking "Busking").^[\[214\]](#cite_note-214)^{#cite_ref-214}  

### Literature {#Literature}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen&action=edit&section=40 "Edit section: Literature")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Koebenhavns_Hovedbibliotek_midterparti.JPG/170px-Koebenhavns_Hovedbibliotek_midterparti.JPG)](/wiki/File:Koebenhavns_Hovedbibliotek_midterparti.JPG) Copenhagen's main public library

Most of Denmarks's major publishing houses are based in Copenhagen. These include the book publishers [Gyldendal](/wiki/Gyldendal "Gyldendal") and [Akademisk Forlag](/wiki/Akademisk_Forlag "Akademisk Forlag") and newspaper publishers [Berlingske](/wiki/Berlingske "Berlingske") and [Politiken](/wiki/JP/Politikens_Hus "JP/Politikens Hus") (the latter also publishing books).^[\[215\]](#cite_note-215)^^[\[216\]](#cite_note-216)^ Many of the most important contributors to Danish literature such as Hans Christian Andersen (1805--1875) with his fairy tales, the philosopher Søren Kierkegaard (1813--1855) and playwright [Ludvig Holberg](/wiki/Ludvig_Holberg "Ludvig Holberg") (1684--1754) spent much of their lives in Copenhagen. Novels set in Copenhagen include *[Baby](/wiki/Baby_(Thorup_novel) "Baby (Thorup novel)")* (1973) by [Kirsten Thorup](/wiki/Kirsten_Thorup "Kirsten Thorup"), *[The Copenhagen Connection](/wiki/The_Copenhagen_Connection_(novel) "The Copenhagen Connection (novel)")* (1982) by [Barbara Mertz](/wiki/Barbara_Mertz "Barbara Mertz"), *[Number the Stars](/wiki/Number_the_Stars "Number the Stars")* (1989) by [Lois Lowry](/wiki/Lois_Lowry "Lois Lowry"), *[Miss Smilla's Feeling for Snow](/wiki/Miss_Smilla%27s_Feeling_for_Snow "Miss Smilla's Feeling for Snow")* (1992) and *[Borderliners](/wiki/Borderliners "Borderliners")* (1993) by [Peter Høeg](/wiki/Peter_H%C3%B8eg "Peter Høeg"), *[Music and Silence](/wiki/Music_and_Silence "Music and Silence")* (1999) by [Rose Tremain](/wiki/Rose_Tremain "Rose Tremain"), *[The Danish Girl](/wiki/The_Danish_Girl "The Danish Girl")* (2000) by [David Ebershoff](/wiki/David_Ebershoff "David Ebershoff"), and *[Sharpe's Prey](/wiki/Sharpe%27s_Prey "Sharpe's Prey")* (2001) by [Bernard Cornwell](/wiki/Bernard_Cornwell "Bernard Cornwell"). [Michael Frayn](/wiki/Michael_Frayn "Michael Frayn")'s 1998 play *[Copenhagen](/wiki/Copenhagen_(play) "Copenhagen (play)")* about the meeting between the [physicists](/wiki/Physicist "Physicist") [Niels Bohr](/wiki/Niels_Bohr "Niels Bohr") and [Werner Heisenberg](/wiki/Werner_Heisenberg "Werner Heisenberg") in 1941 is also set in the city. On 15--18 August 1973, an oral literature conference took place in Copenhagen as part of the 9th International Congress of Anthropological and Ethnological Sciences.^[\[217\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJasonSegal19777-217)^{#cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJasonSegal19777_217-0}

The [Royal Library](/wiki/Royal_Library,_Denmark "Royal Library, Denmark"), belonging to the [University of Copenhagen](/wiki/University_of_Copenhagen "University of Copenhagen"), is the largest library in the Nordic countries with an almost complete collection of all printed Danish books since 1482. Founded in 1648, the Royal Library is located at four sites in the city, the main one being on the Slotsholmen waterfront.^[\[218\]](#cite_note-218)^ Copenhagen's public library network has over 20 outlets, the largest being the Central Library (*Københavns Hovedbibliotek*) on [Krystalgade](/wiki/Krystalgade "Krystalgade") in the inner city.^[\[219\]](#cite_note-219)^{#cite_ref-219}  

### Art {#Art}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen&action=edit&section=41 "Edit section: Art")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Statens_Museum_for_Kunst.jpg/150px-Statens_Museum_for_Kunst.jpg)](/wiki/File:Statens_Museum_for_Kunst.jpg) Interior of the National Gallery (*Statens Museum for Kunst*), combining new and old architecture

Copenhagen has a wide selection of art museums and galleries displaying both historic works and more modern contributions. They include [Statens Museum for Kunst](/wiki/National_Gallery_of_Denmark "National Gallery of Denmark"), i.e. the Danish national art gallery, in the [Østre Anlæg](/wiki/%C3%98stre_Anl%C3%A6g "Østre Anlæg") park, and the adjacent [Hirschsprung Collection](/wiki/Hirschsprung_Collection "Hirschsprung Collection") specialising in the 19th and early 20th century. [Kunsthal Charlottenborg](/wiki/Kunsthal_Charlottenborg "Kunsthal Charlottenborg") in the city centre exhibits national and international contemporary art. [Den Frie Udstilling](/wiki/Den_Frie_Udstilling "Den Frie Udstilling") near the [Østerport Station](/wiki/%C3%98sterport_Station "Østerport Station") exhibits paintings created and selected by contemporary artists themselves rather than by the official authorities. The [Arken Museum of Modern Art](/wiki/Arken_Museum_of_Modern_Art "Arken Museum of Modern Art") is located in southwestern [Ishøj](/wiki/Ish%C3%B8j "Ishøj").^[\[220\]](#cite_note-220)^ Among artists who have painted scenes of Copenhagen are [Martinus Rørbye](/wiki/Martinus_R%C3%B8rbye "Martinus Rørbye") (1803--1848),^[\[221\]](#cite_note-221)^ [Christen Købke](/wiki/Christen_K%C3%B8bke "Christen Købke") (1810--1848)^[\[222\]](#cite_note-222)^ and the prolific [Paul Gustav Fischer](/wiki/Paul_Gustav_Fischer "Paul Gustav Fischer") (1860--1934).^[\[223\]](#cite_note-223)^{#cite_ref-223}

A number of notable sculptures can be seen in the city. In addition to *The Little Mermaid* on the waterfront, there are two historic equestrian statues in the city centre: [Jacques Saly](/wiki/Jacques_Saly "Jacques Saly")'s *[Frederik V on Horseback](/wiki/Frederik_V_on_Horseback "Frederik V on Horseback")* (1771) in Amalienborg Square^[\[224\]](#cite_note-224)^ and the statue of [Christian V](/wiki/Christian_V_of_Denmark "Christian V of Denmark") on Kongens Nytorv created by Abraham-César Lamoureux in 1688 who was inspired by the statue of [Louis XIII](/wiki/Louis_XIII_of_France "Louis XIII of France") in Paris.^[\[225\]](#cite_note-Nørregård-Nielsen2009-225)^ [Rosenborg Castle Gardens](/wiki/List_of_public_art_in_Rosenborg_Castle_Gardens "List of public art in Rosenborg Castle Gardens") contains several sculptures and monuments including [August Saabye](/wiki/August_Saabye "August Saabye")'s Hans Christian Andersen, [Aksel Hansen](/wiki/Aksel_Hansen "Aksel Hansen")'s Echo, and [Vilhelm Bissen](/wiki/Vilhelm_Bissen "Vilhelm Bissen")'s [Dowager Queen Caroline Amalie](/wiki/Caroline_Amalie_of_Augustenburg "Caroline Amalie of Augustenburg").^[\[226\]](#cite_note-226)^{#cite_ref-226}

Copenhagen is believed to have invented the [photomarathon](/wiki/Photomarathon "Photomarathon") photography competition, which has been held in the City each year since 1989.^[\[227\]](#cite_note-227)^^[\[228\]](#cite_note-228)^{#cite_ref-228}  

### Cuisine {#Cuisine}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen&action=edit&section=42 "Edit section: Cuisine")\]  
For a broader look at this topic, see [Danish cuisine](/wiki/Danish_cuisine "Danish cuisine").
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Noma_entrance.jpg/220px-Noma_entrance.jpg)](/wiki/File:Noma_entrance.jpg) Noma is an example of Copenhagen's renowned experimental restaurants, and has gained three [Michelin stars](/wiki/Michelin_Guide "Michelin Guide").

As of 2014^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen&action=edit)^, Copenhagen has 15 [Michelin-starred](/wiki/Michelin_Guide "Michelin Guide") restaurants, the most of any Scandinavian city.^[\[229\]](#cite_note-229)^ The city is increasingly recognized internationally as a gourmet destination.^[\[230\]](#cite_note-230)^ These include Den Røde Cottage, Formel B Restaurant, Grønbech \& Churchill, Søllerød Kro, Kadeau, Kiin Kiin (Denmark's first Michelin-starred Asian gourmet restaurant), the French restaurant Kong Hans Kælder, Relæ, Restaurant AOC with two Stars, and [Noma](/wiki/Noma_(restaurant) "Noma (restaurant)") (short for [Danish](/wiki/Danish_language "Danish language"): *nordisk* *mad* , English: Nordic food) as well as [Geranium](/wiki/Geranium_(restaurant) "Geranium (restaurant)") with three. Noma was ranked as the [Best Restaurant in the World](/wiki/Restaurant_(magazine)_Top_50 "Restaurant (magazine) Top 50") by *[Restaurant](/wiki/Restaurant_(magazine) "Restaurant (magazine)")* in 2010, 2011, 2012, and again in 2014,^[\[231\]](#cite_note-231)^ sparking interest in the [New Nordic Cuisine](/wiki/New_Nordic_Cuisine "New Nordic Cuisine").^[\[232\]](#cite_note-232)^{#cite_ref-232}

Apart from the selection of upmarket restaurants, Copenhagen offers a great variety of Danish, ethnic and experimental restaurants. It is possible to find modest eateries serving [open sandwiches](/wiki/Open_sandwich "Open sandwich"), known as [smørrebrød](/wiki/Sm%C3%B8rrebr%C3%B8d "Smørrebrød") -- a traditional, Danish lunch dish; however, most restaurants serve international dishes.^[\[233\]](#cite_note-233)^ [Danish pastry](/wiki/Danish_pastry "Danish pastry") can be sampled from any of numerous bakeries found in all parts of the city. The Copenhagen Bakers' Association (Danish: *Københavns Bagerlaug*) dates back to the 1290s and Denmark's oldest confectioner's shop still operating, *Conditori La Glace* , was founded in 1870 in Skoubogade by Nicolaus Henningsen, a trained master baker from [Flensburg](/wiki/Flensburg "Flensburg").^[\[234\]](#cite_note-234)^{#cite_ref-234}

Copenhagen has long been associated with beer. [Carlsberg](/wiki/Carlsberg_Group "Carlsberg Group") beer has been brewed at the brewery's premises on the border between the [Vesterbro](/wiki/Vesterbro,_Copenhagen "Vesterbro, Copenhagen") and [Valby](/wiki/Valby "Valby") districts since 1847 and has long been almost synonymous with [Danish beer](/wiki/Beer_in_Denmark "Beer in Denmark") production. However, recent years have seen an explosive growth in the number of [microbreweries](/wiki/Microbrewery "Microbrewery") so that Denmark today has more than 100 breweries, many of which are located in Copenhagen. Some like Nørrebro Bryghus also act as [brewpubs](/wiki/Brewpubs "Brewpubs") where it is also possible to eat on the premises.^[\[235\]](#cite_note-235)^^[\[236\]](#cite_note-236)^{#cite_ref-236}  

### Nightlife and festivals {#Nightlife_and_festivals}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen&action=edit&section=43 "Edit section: Nightlife and festivals")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Copenhagen_Pride_2008_i.JPG/220px-Copenhagen_Pride_2008_i.JPG)](/wiki/File:Copenhagen_Pride_2008_i.JPG) Copenhagen [Pride Parade](/wiki/Pride_Parade "Pride Parade"), 2008

Copenhagen has one of the highest number of restaurants and bars per capita in the world.^[\[237\]](#cite_note-237)^ The nightclubs and bars stay open until 5 or 6 in the morning, some even longer. Denmark has a very liberal alcohol culture and a strong tradition for beer breweries, although binge drinking is frowned upon and the Danish Police take [driving under the influence](/wiki/Driving_under_the_influence "Driving under the influence") very seriously.^[\[238\]](#cite_note-238)^ Inner city areas such as [Istedgade](/wiki/Istedgade "Istedgade") and [Enghave Plads](/wiki/Enghave_Plads "Enghave Plads") in Vesterbro, [Sankt Hans Torv](/wiki/Sankt_Hans_Torv "Sankt Hans Torv") in Nørrebro and certain places in Frederiksberg are especially noted for their [nightlife](/wiki/Nightlife "Nightlife"). Notable nightclubs include Bakken Kbh, ARCH (previously ZEN), Jolene, The Jane, Chateau Motel, KB3, At Dolores (previously Sunday Club), Rust, Vega Nightclub and Culture Box .^[\[239\]](#cite_note-239)^^[\[240\]](#cite_note-240)^{#cite_ref-240}

Copenhagen has several recurring community festivals, mainly in the summer. [Copenhagen Carnival](/wiki/Copenhagen_Carnival "Copenhagen Carnival") has taken place every year since 1982 during the [Whitsun](/wiki/Whitsun "Whitsun") Holiday in [Fælledparken](/wiki/F%C3%A6lledparken "Fælledparken") and around the city with the participation of 120 bands, 2,000 dancers and 100,000 spectators.^[\[241\]](#cite_note-Timeline-241)^ Since 2010, the old B\&W Shipyard at [Refshaleøen](/wiki/Refshale%C3%B8en "Refshaleøen") in the harbour has been the location for [Copenhell](/wiki/Copenhell "Copenhell"), a [heavy metal](/wiki/Heavy_metal_music "Heavy metal music") rock music festival. [Copenhagen Pride](/wiki/Copenhagen_Pride "Copenhagen Pride") is a [LGBT pride](/wiki/LGBT_pride "LGBT pride") festival taking place every year in August. The Pride has a series of different activities all over Copenhagen, but it is at the [City Hall Square](/wiki/City_Hall_Square,_Copenhagen "City Hall Square, Copenhagen") that most of the celebration takes place. During the Pride the square is renamed Pride Square.^[\[242\]](#cite_note-242)^ [Copenhagen Distortion](/wiki/Copenhagen_Distortion "Copenhagen Distortion") has emerged to be one of the biggest street festivals in Europe with 100,000 people joining to parties in the beginning of June every year.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^{#cite_ref-242}  

### Amusement parks {#Amusement_parks}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen&action=edit&section=44 "Edit section: Amusement parks")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Pantomime_Theatre.jpg/220px-Pantomime_Theatre.jpg)](/wiki/File:Pantomime_Theatre.jpg) The [Pantomime Theatre](/wiki/Pantomimeteatret "Pantomimeteatret"), opened in 1874, is the oldest building in the Tivoli Gardens.

Copenhagen has the oldest and third-oldest [amusement parks](/wiki/Amusement_parks "Amusement parks") in the world.^[\[243\]](#cite_note-www3-243)^^[\[244\]](#cite_note-244)^{#cite_ref-244}

[Dyrehavsbakken](/wiki/Dyrehavsbakken "Dyrehavsbakken"), a fair-ground and pleasure-park established in 1583, is located in [Klampenborg](/wiki/Klampenborg "Klampenborg") just north of Copenhagen in a forested area known as [Dyrehaven](/wiki/J%C3%A6gersborg_Dyrehave "Jægersborg Dyrehave"). Created as an amusement park complete with rides, games and restaurants by [Christian IV](/wiki/Christian_IV_of_Denmark "Christian IV of Denmark"), it is the oldest surviving amusement park in the world.^[\[243\]](#cite_note-www3-243)^ [Pierrot](/wiki/Pierrot#Denmark "Pierrot") (Danish: *Pjerrot* ), a nitwit dressed in white with a scarlet grin wearing a boat-like hat while entertaining children, remains one of the park's key attractions. In Danish, Dyrehavsbakken is often abbreviated as *Bakken*. There is no entrance fee to pay and [Klampenborg Station](/wiki/Klampenborg_Station "Klampenborg Station") on the [C-line](/wiki/C_(S-train) "C (S-train)"), is situated nearby.^[\[245\]](#cite_note-245)^{#cite_ref-245}

The [Tivoli Gardens](/wiki/Tivoli_Gardens "Tivoli Gardens") is an amusement park and pleasure garden located in central Copenhagen between the [City Hall Square](/wiki/The_City_Hall_Square,_Copenhagen "The City Hall Square, Copenhagen") and the [Central Station](/wiki/Copenhagen_Central_Station "Copenhagen Central Station"). It opened in 1843, making it the third-oldest amusement park in the world, the second being [Wurstelprater](/wiki/Wurstelprater "Wurstelprater") in Vienna. Among its rides are the oldest still operating rollercoaster *Rutschebanen* from 1915 and the oldest [ferris wheel](/wiki/Ferris_wheel "Ferris wheel") still in use, opened in 1943.^[\[246\]](#cite_note-246)^ Tivoli Gardens also serves as a venue for various performing arts and as an active part of the cultural scene in Copenhagen.^[\[247\]](#cite_note-247)^{#cite_ref-247}  

Education {#Education}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen&action=edit&section=45 "Edit section: Education")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Kbh_Universitaet_2.jpg/220px-Kbh_Universitaet_2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Kbh_Universitaet_2.jpg) The main building of the University of Copenhagen

Copenhagen has over 94,000 students enrolled in its largest universities and institutions: [University of Copenhagen](/wiki/University_of_Copenhagen "University of Copenhagen") (38,867 students),^[\[248\]](#cite_note-248)^ [Copenhagen Business School](/wiki/Copenhagen_Business_School "Copenhagen Business School") (20,000 students),^[\[249\]](#cite_note-249)^ [Metropolitan University College](/wiki/Metropolitan_University_College "Metropolitan University College") and [University College Capital](/wiki/University_College_Capital "University College Capital") (10,000 students each),^[\[250\]](#cite_note-250)^ [Technical University of Denmark](/wiki/Technical_University_of_Denmark "Technical University of Denmark") (7,000 students),^[\[251\]](#cite_note-251)^ KEA (c. 4,500 students),^[\[252\]](#cite_note-252)^ [IT University of Copenhagen](/wiki/IT_University_of_Copenhagen "IT University of Copenhagen") (2,000 students) and the [Copenhagen campus](/wiki/Aalborg_University_%E2%80%93_Copenhagen "Aalborg University – Copenhagen") of [Aalborg University](/wiki/Aalborg_University "Aalborg University") (2,300 students).^[\[253\]](#cite_note-253)^{#cite_ref-253}

The University of Copenhagen is Denmark's oldest university founded in 1479. It attracts some 1,500 international and exchange students every year. The [Academic Ranking of World Universities](/wiki/Academic_Ranking_of_World_Universities "Academic Ranking of World Universities") placed it 30th in the world in 2016.^[\[254\]](#cite_note-254)^{#cite_ref-254}

The Technical University of Denmark is located in [Lyngby](/wiki/Kongens_Lyngby "Kongens Lyngby") in the northern outskirts of Copenhagen. In 2013, it was ranked as one of the leading technical universities in Northern Europe.^[\[255\]](#cite_note-255)^ The IT University is Denmark's youngest university, a mono-faculty institution focusing on technical, societal and business aspects of information technology.^[\[256\]](#cite_note-256)^{#cite_ref-256}

The [Danish Academy of Fine Arts](/wiki/Danish_Academy_of_Fine_Arts "Danish Academy of Fine Arts") has provided education in the arts for more than 250 years. It includes the historic School of Visual Arts, and has in later years come to include a [School of Architecture](/wiki/Kunstakademiets_Arkitektskole "Kunstakademiets Arkitektskole"), a [School of Design](/wiki/Danmarks_Designskole "Danmarks Designskole") and a School of Conservation.^[\[257\]](#cite_note-257)^ [Copenhagen Business School](/wiki/Copenhagen_Business_School "Copenhagen Business School") (CBS) is an [EQUIS](/wiki/European_Quality_Improvement_System "European Quality Improvement System")-accredited business school located in [Frederiksberg](/wiki/Frederiksberg_Municipality "Frederiksberg Municipality").^[\[258\]](#cite_note-258)^ There are also branches of both [University College Capital](/wiki/University_College_Capital "University College Capital") and [Metropolitan University College](/wiki/Metropolitan_University_College "Metropolitan University College") inside and outside Copenhagen.^[\[259\]](#cite_note-259)^^[\[260\]](#cite_note-260)^{#cite_ref-260}  

Sport {#Sport}
--------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen&action=edit&section=46 "Edit section: Sport")\]

The city has a variety of sporting teams. The major [football](/wiki/Association_football "Association football") teams are the historically successful [FC København](/wiki/F.C._Copenhagen "F.C. Copenhagen")^[\[261\]](#cite_note-261)^ and [Brøndby](/wiki/Br%C3%B8ndby_IF "Brøndby IF"). FC København plays at [Parken](/wiki/Parken_Stadium "Parken Stadium") in Østerbro. Formed in 1992, it is a merger of two older Copenhagen clubs, [B 1903](/wiki/B_1903 "B 1903") (from the inner suburb Gentofte) and [KB](/wiki/Kj%C3%B8benhavns_Boldklub "Kjøbenhavns Boldklub") (from Frederiksberg).^[\[262\]](#cite_note-262)^ Brøndby plays at [Brøndby Stadion](/wiki/Br%C3%B8ndby_Stadion "Brøndby Stadion") in the inner suburb of [Brøndbyvester](/wiki/Br%C3%B8ndbyvester "Brøndbyvester"). [BK Frem](/wiki/BK_Frem "BK Frem") is based in the southern part of Copenhagen (Sydhavnen, Valby). Other teams of more significant stature are [FC Nordsjælland](/wiki/FC_Nordsj%C3%A6lland "FC Nordsjælland") (from suburban [Farum](/wiki/Farum "Farum")), [Fremad Amager](/wiki/Fremad_Amager "Fremad Amager"), [B93](/wiki/Boldklubben_1893 "Boldklubben 1893"), [AB](/wiki/Akademisk_Boldklub "Akademisk Boldklub"), [Lyngby](/wiki/Lyngby_Boldklub "Lyngby Boldklub") and [Hvidovre IF](/wiki/Hvidovre_IF "Hvidovre IF").^[\[263\]](#cite_note-nysport-263)^{#cite_ref-nysport_263-0}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Copenhagen_Marathon_2008.jpg/220px-Copenhagen_Marathon_2008.jpg)](/wiki/File:Copenhagen_Marathon_2008.jpg) Copenhagen Marathon, 2008

Copenhagen has several [handball teams](/wiki/Team_handball "Team handball")---a sport which is particularly popular in Denmark. Of clubs playing in the "highest" leagues, there are Ajax, Ydun, and HIK ([Hellerup](/wiki/Hellerup "Hellerup")).^[\[263\]](#cite_note-nysport-263)^ The [København Håndbold](/wiki/K%C3%B8benhavn_H%C3%A5ndbold "København Håndbold") women's club has recently been established.^[\[264\]](#cite_note-264)^ Copenhagen also has [ice hockey](/wiki/Ice_hockey "Ice hockey") teams, of which three play in the top league, [Rødovre Mighty Bulls](/wiki/R%C3%B8dovre_Mighty_Bulls "Rødovre Mighty Bulls"), [Herlev Eagles](/wiki/Herlev_Hornets "Herlev Hornets") and [Hvidovre Ligahockey](/wiki/Hvidovre_Ligahockey "Hvidovre Ligahockey") all inner suburban clubs. [Copenhagen Ice Skating Club](/wiki/Kj%C3%B8benhavns_Sk%C3%B8jtel%C3%B8berforening "Kjøbenhavns Skøjteløberforening") founded in 1869 is the oldest ice hockey team in Denmark but is no longer in the top league.^[\[265\]](#cite_note-265)^{#cite_ref-265}

[Rugby union](/wiki/Rugby_union "Rugby union") is also played in the Danish capital with teams such as [CSR-Nanok](/wiki/CSR-Nanok "CSR-Nanok"), Copenhagen Business School Sport Rugby, [Frederiksberg RK](/wiki/Frederiksberg_RK "Frederiksberg RK"), [Exiles RUFC](/wiki/Exiles_RUFC "Exiles RUFC") and [Rugbyklubben Speed](/wiki/RK_Speed "RK Speed"). [Rugby league](/wiki/Rugby_league "Rugby league") is now played in Copenhagen, with the national team playing out of [Gentofte Stadion](/wiki/Gentofte_Stadion "Gentofte Stadion"). The [Danish Australian Football League](/wiki/Danish_Australian_Football_League "Danish Australian Football League"), based in Copenhagen is the largest [Australian rules football](/wiki/Australian_rules_football "Australian rules football") competition outside of the [English-speaking world](/wiki/English-speaking_world "English-speaking world").^[\[263\]](#cite_note-nysport-263)^^[\[266\]](#cite_note-266)^{#cite_ref-266}

[Copenhagen Marathon](/wiki/Copenhagen_Marathon "Copenhagen Marathon"), Copenhagen's annual [marathon](/wiki/Marathon "Marathon") event, was established in 1980.^[\[267\]](#cite_note-267)^ [Round Christiansborg Open Water Swim Race](/wiki/Slotsholmen#Round_Christiansborg_Open_Water_Swim "Slotsholmen") is a 2-kilometre (1.2-mile) [open water swimming](/wiki/Open_water_swimming "Open water swimming") competition taking place each year in late August.^[\[268\]](#cite_note-268)^ This amateur event is combined with a 10-kilometre (6-mile) Danish championship.^[\[269\]](#cite_note-269)^ In 2009 the event included a 10-kilometre (6-mile) FINA World Cup competition in the morning. Copenhagen hosted the [2011 UCI Road World Championships](/wiki/2011_UCI_Road_World_Championships "2011 UCI Road World Championships") in September 2011, taking advantage of its bicycle-friendly infrastructure. It was the first time that Denmark had hosted the event since 1956, when it was also held in Copenhagen.^[\[270\]](#cite_note-270)^{#cite_ref-270}  

Transport {#Transport}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen&action=edit&section=47 "Edit section: Transport")\]  
Main article: [Transport in Copenhagen](/wiki/Transport_in_Copenhagen "Transport in Copenhagen")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Copenhagen_from_air.jpg/280px-Copenhagen_from_air.jpg)](/wiki/File:Copenhagen_from_air.jpg) Aerial view of Copenhagen seen from an airplane departing from Copenhagen Airport  

### Airport {#Airport}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen&action=edit&section=48 "Edit section: Airport")\]

The greater Copenhagen area has a very well established transportation infrastructure making it a hub in Northern Europe. [Copenhagen Airport](/wiki/Copenhagen_Airport "Copenhagen Airport"), opened in 1925, is Scandinavia's largest airport, located in [Kastrup](/wiki/Kastrup "Kastrup") on the island of Amager. It is connected to the city centre by metro and main line railway services.^[\[271\]](#cite_note-271)^ October 2013 was a record month with 2.2 million passengers, and November 2013 figures reveal that the number of passengers is increasing by some 3% annually, about 50% more than the European average.^[\[272\]](#cite_note-272)^{#cite_ref-272}  

### Road, rail and ferry {#Road.2C_rail_and_ferry}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen&action=edit&section=49 "Edit section: Road, rail and ferry")\]

Copenhagen has an extensive road network including motorways connecting the city to other parts of Denmark and to Sweden over the [Øresund Bridge](/wiki/%C3%98resund_Bridge "Øresund Bridge").^[\[273\]](#cite_note-nt-273)^ The car is still the most popular form of transport within the city itself, representing two-thirds of all distances travelled. This can however lead to serious congestion in rush hour traffic.^[\[274\]](#cite_note-274)^ The Øresund train links Copenhagen with Malmö 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. Copenhagen is also served by a daily ferry connection to [Oslo](/wiki/Oslo "Oslo") in Norway.^[\[275\]](#cite_note-ferry-275)^ In 2012, Copenhagen Harbour handled 372 cruise ships and 840,000 passengers.^[\[275\]](#cite_note-ferry-275)^{#cite_ref-ferry_275-1}

The [Copenhagen S-Train](/wiki/S-train_(Copenhagen) "S-train (Copenhagen)"), [Copenhagen Metro](/wiki/Copenhagen_Metro "Copenhagen Metro") and the regional train networks are used by about half of the city's passengers, the remainder using bus services. [Nørreport Station](/wiki/N%C3%B8rreport_Station "Nørreport Station") near the city centre serves passengers travelling by main-line rail, [S-train](/wiki/S-train "S-train"), regional train, metro and bus. Some 750,000 passengers make use of public transport facilities every day.^[\[273\]](#cite_note-nt-273)^ [Copenhagen Central Station](/wiki/Copenhagen_Central_Station "Copenhagen Central Station") is the hub of the [DSB](/wiki/DSB_(railway_company) "DSB (railway company)") railway network serving Denmark and international destinations.^[\[276\]](#cite_note-276)^{#cite_ref-276}

The [Copenhagen Metro](/wiki/Copenhagen_Metro "Copenhagen Metro") expanded radically with the opening of the [City Circle Line](/wiki/City_Circle_Line "City Circle Line") (M3) on 29 September 2019.^[\[277\]](#cite_note-277)^ The new line connects all inner boroughs of the city by metro, including the [Central Station](/wiki/Copenhagen_Central_Station "Copenhagen Central Station"), and opens up 17 new stations^[\[278\]](#cite_note-278)^ for Copenhageners. On 28 March 2020, the 2.2 km (1.4 mi) Nordhavn extension of the Harbour Line ([M4](/wiki/M4_(Copenhagen_Metro) "M4 (Copenhagen Metro)")) opened.^[\[279\]](#cite_note-279)^ Running from [Copenhagen Central Station](/wiki/Copenhagen_Central_Station "Copenhagen Central Station"), the new extension is a branch line of [M3](/wiki/M3_(Copenhagen) "M3 (Copenhagen)") Cityring to Østerport.^[\[280\]](#cite_note-280)^ The new metro lines are part of the city's strategy to transform mobility towards sustainable modes of transport such as public transport and cycling as opposed to automobility.^[\[281\]](#cite_note-281)^{#cite_ref-281}

Copenhagen is cited by urban planners for its exemplary integration of public transport and urban development. In implementing its [Finger Plan](/wiki/Finger_Plan "Finger Plan"), Copenhagen is considered the world's first example of a [transit metropolis](/wiki/Transit_metropolis "Transit metropolis"),^[\[53\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTECervero1998132-53)^ and areas around S-Train stations like [Ballerup](/wiki/Ballerup "Ballerup") and [Brøndby Strand](/wiki/Br%C3%B8ndby_Strand "Brøndby Strand") are among the earliest examples of [transit-oriented development](/wiki/Transit-oriented_development "Transit-oriented development").^[\[282\]](#cite_note-282)^{#cite_ref-282}  

### Cycling {#Cycling}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen&action=edit&section=50 "Edit section: Cycling")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Copenhagen_bicycles_at_Christianshavn_Metro_Station.JPG/220px-Copenhagen_bicycles_at_Christianshavn_Metro_Station.JPG)](/wiki/File:Copenhagen_bicycles_at_Christianshavn_Metro_Station.JPG) The intense use of bicycles in Copenhagen illustrated here at the [Christianshavn Metro station](/wiki/Christianshavn_station "Christianshavn station")  
Main article: [Cycling in Copenhagen](/wiki/Cycling_in_Copenhagen "Cycling in Copenhagen")  
See also: [Cycling advocacy § Copenhagenization](/wiki/Cycling_advocacy#Copenhagenization "Cycling advocacy")

Copenhagen has been rated as one of the most [bicycle-friendly](/wiki/Bicycle-friendly "Bicycle-friendly") cities in the world since 2015, with bicycles outnumbering its inhabitants.^[\[283\]](#cite_note-283)^^[\[284\]](#cite_note-284)^^[\[285\]](#cite_note-Copenhagen's_piles_of_bicycles-285)^ In 2012 some 36% of all working or studying city-dwellers cycled to work, school, or university. With 1.27 million km covered every working day by [Copenhagen's cyclists](/wiki/Cycling_in_Copenhagen "Cycling in Copenhagen") (including both residents and commuters), and 75% of Copenhageners cycling throughout the year.^[\[286\]](#cite_note-286)^ The city's [bicycle paths](/wiki/Cycling_infrastructure "Cycling infrastructure") are extensive and well used, boasting 400 kilometres (250 miles) of cycle lanes not shared with cars or pedestrians, and sometimes have their own signal systems -- giving the cyclists a lead of a couple of seconds to accelerate.^[\[285\]](#cite_note-Copenhagen's_piles_of_bicycles-285)^^[\[287\]](#cite_note-287)^{#cite_ref-287}  

Healthcare {#Healthcare}
------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen&action=edit&section=51 "Edit section: Healthcare")\]  
See also: [Healthcare in Denmark](/wiki/Healthcare_in_Denmark "Healthcare in Denmark")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Rigshospitalet_Copenhagen_2005-11.jpg/220px-Rigshospitalet_Copenhagen_2005-11.jpg)](/wiki/File:Rigshospitalet_Copenhagen_2005-11.jpg) Rigshospitalet is one of the largest hospitals in Denmark.

Promoting health is an important issue for Copenhagen's municipal authorities. Central to its sustainability mission is its "Long Live Copenhagen" (*Længe Leve København*) scheme in which it has the goal of increasing the life expectancy of citizens, improving quality of life through better standards of health, and encouraging more productive lives and equal opportunities.^[\[288\]](#cite_note-kkhealth-288)^ The city has targets to encourage people to exercise regularly and to reduce the number who smoke and consume alcohol.^[\[288\]](#cite_note-kkhealth-288)^{#cite_ref-kkhealth_288-1}

[Copenhagen University Hospital](/wiki/Copenhagen_University_Hospital "Copenhagen University Hospital") forms a conglomerate of several hospitals in [Region Hovedstaden](/wiki/Region_Hovedstaden "Region Hovedstaden") and [Region Sjælland](/wiki/Region_Sj%C3%A6lland "Region Sjælland"), together with the faculty of [health sciences](/wiki/Health_sciences "Health sciences") at the University of Copenhagen; [Rigshospitalet](/wiki/Rigshospitalet "Rigshospitalet") and [Bispebjerg Hospital](/wiki/Bispebjerg_Hospital "Bispebjerg Hospital") in Copenhagen belong to this group of university hospitals.^[\[289\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKjaerKrogsgaardMagnussonLars_Engebretsen200811-289)^ Rigshospitalet began operating in March 1757 as Frederiks Hospital,^[\[290\]](#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchaldemose2005107-290)^ and became state-owned in 1903. With 1,120 beds, Rigshospitalet has responsibility for 65,000 inpatients and approximately 420,000 outpatients annually. It seeks to be the number one specialist hospital in the country, with an extensive team of researchers into cancer treatment, surgery and radiotherapy.^[\[291\]](#cite_note-291)^ In addition to its 8,000 personnel, the hospital has training and hosting functions. It benefits from the presence of in-service students of medicine and other healthcare sciences, as well as scientists working under a variety of research grants. The hospital became internationally famous as the location of [Lars von Trier](/wiki/Lars_von_Trier "Lars von Trier")'s television horror mini-series *[The Kingdom](/wiki/Riget "Riget")* . Bispebjerg Hospital was built in 1913, and serves about 400,000 people in the Greater Copenhagen area, with some 3,000 employees.^[\[292\]](#cite_note-292)^ Other large hospitals in the city include [Amager Hospital](/wiki/Amager_Hospital "Amager Hospital") (1997),^[\[293\]](#cite_note-293)^ [Herlev Hospital](/wiki/Herlev_Hospital "Herlev Hospital") (1976),^[\[294\]](#cite_note-294)^ [Hvidovre Hospital](/wiki/Hvidovre_Hospital "Hvidovre Hospital") (1970),^[\[295\]](#cite_note-295)^ and [Gentofte Hospital](/wiki/Gentofte_Hospital "Gentofte Hospital") (1927).^[\[296\]](#cite_note-296)^{#cite_ref-296}  

Media {#Media}
--------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Copenhagen&action=edit&section=52 "Edit section: Media")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Aller_Media%2C_Havneholmen%2C_Copenhagen.jpg/170px-Aller_Media%2C_Havneholmen%2C_Copenhagen.jpg)](/wiki/File:Aller_Media,_Havneholmen,_Copenhagen.jpg) The Aller Media conglomerate building in Havneholm

Many Danish media corporations are located in Copenhagen. [DR](/wiki/DR_(broadcaster) "DR (broadcaster)"), the major Danish [public service](/wiki/Public_broadcasting "Public broadcasting") broadcasting corporation consolidated its activities in a new headquarters, [DR Byen](/wiki/DR_Byen "DR Byen"), in 2006 and 2007. Similarly [TV2](/wiki/TV_2_(Denmark) "TV 2 (Denmark)"), which is based in [Odense](/wiki/Odense "Odense"), has concentrated its Copenhagen activities in a modern media house in [Teglholmen](/wiki/Teglholmen "Teglholmen").^[\[297\]](#cite_note-297)^ The two national daily newspapers *[Politiken](/wiki/Politiken "Politiken")* and *[Berlingske](/wiki/Berlingske "Berlingske")* and the two [tabloids](/wiki/Tabloid_(newspaper_format) "Tabloid (newspaper format)") *[Ekstra Bladet](/wiki/Ekstra_Bladet "Ekstra Bladet")* and *[BT](/wiki/B.T._(tabloid) "B.T. (tabloid)")* are based in Copenhagen.^[\[298\]](#cite_note-298)^ *[Kristeligt Dagblad](/wiki/Kristeligt_Dagblad "Kristeligt Dagblad")* is based in Copenhagen and is published six days a week.^[\[299\]](#cite_note-299)^ Other important media corporations include [Aller Media](/wiki/Aller_Media "Aller Media") which is the largest publisher of weekly and monthly magazines in [Scandinavia](/wiki/Scandinavia "Scandinavia"),^[\[300\]](#cite_note-300)^ the [Egmont](/wiki/Egmont_Publishing "Egmont Publishing") [media group](/wiki/Media_conglomerate "Media conglomerate")^[\[301\]](#cite_note-301)^ and [Gyldendal](/wiki/Gyldendal "Gyldendal"), the largest Danish publisher of books.^[\[302\]](#cite_note-302)^{#cite_ref-302}

Copenhagen has a large film and television industry. [Nordisk Film](/wiki/Nordisk_Film "Nordisk Film"), established in Valby, Copenhagen in 1906 is the oldest continuously operating film production company in the world.^[\[241\]](#cite_note-Timeline-241)^ In 1992 it merged with the Egmont media group and currently runs the 17-screen [Palads Cinema](/wiki/Palads_Cinema "Palads Cinema") in Copenhagen. [Filmbyen](/wiki/Filmbyen "Filmbyen") (movie city), located in a former [military camp](/wiki/Military_camp "Military camp") in the suburb of [Hvidovre](/wiki/Hvidovre "Hvidovre"), houses several movie companies and [studios](/wiki/Movie_studio "Movie studio"). [Zentropa](/wiki/Zentropa "Zentropa") is a film company, co-owned by Danish [director](/wiki/Film_director "Film director") [Lars von Trier](/wiki/Lars_von_Trier "Lars von Trier"). He is behind several international movie productions as well and founded the [Dogme Movement](/wiki/Dogme_95 "Dogme 95").^[\[303\]](#cite_note-303)^ [CPH:PIX](/wiki/CPH:PIX "CPH:PIX") is Copenhagen's international feature film festival, established in 2009 as a fusion of the 20-year-old [NatFilm Festival](/wiki/NatFilm_Festival "NatFilm Festival") and the four-year-old CIFF. The CPH:PIX festival takes place in mid-April. [CPH:DOX](/wiki/Copenhagen_International_Documentary_Festival "Copenhagen International Documentary Festival") is Copenhagen's international documentary film festival, every year in November. In addition to a documentary film programme of over 100 films, CPH:DOX includes a wide [event programme](/wiki/Programme_(booklet) "Programme (booklet)") with dozens of events, concerts, exhibitions and parties all over town.^[\[304\]](#cite_note-cphpix1-304)^{#cite_ref-cphpix1_304-0}
